prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,'
responses:
# The Habit of Truth

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how often do I turn away, preferring comfort's sweet embrace?
The mirror you hold reflects what I fear to face,
While I construct elaborate shelters of delusion.

Each morning I promise to honor your voice,
To let your whispers guide my choices and words.
Yet by midday, I've forgotten our pact,
Seduced by convenience, by what others expect.

You wait patiently in the corners of consciousness,
Neither judging nor forcing your presence upon me.
You simply exist, eternal and unchanging,
While I dance around you, sometimes drawing near.

What would happen if I made you my constant companion?
If I cleared the pathways between us of debris?
Would my relationships deepen, roots stretching into fertile soil?
Would my art finally speak with the resonance I seek?

The habit of listening requires silence first,
A willingness to sit with discomfort, with uncertainty.
To recognize that you speak in many voices—
Through body and dream, through stranger and friend.

Truth! I shall speak you when I learn to listen,
When I practice the discipline of attention.
When I value clarity more than being right,
When I understand that you are not a weapon, but a light.

# Listening for Truth

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my ears are often filled with noise of my own making,
The clamor of desires, the static of fear,
The comfortable hum of long-held beliefs.

I have searched for you in sacred texts and scholarly tomes,
In the declarations of those who claim your authority,
Yet found instead pale imitations, fragments,
Pieces of you filtered through human limitation.

You do not announce yourself with trumpets or thunder,
But arrive quietly, like morning dew on grass,
Settling into the spaces between thoughts,
Waiting to be noticed by those who have learned stillness.

Sometimes you appear in unexpected guises—
In the mouth of a child, in the eyes of the dying,
In moments of failure when illusions fall away,
Revealing the bedrock beneath my constructed self.

The habit of listening requires daily practice,
A turning toward rather than away,
An acknowledgment that you may contradict
Everything I've built my life upon.

How terrifying, this commitment to your voice!
Yet how liberating to release the weight of falsehood,
To align my words with what I know most deeply,
To become a vessel through which you flow unimpeded.

Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
When I've cultivated the courage to hear,
When I understand that you are not possession but relationship,
A conversation that continues until my final breath.

# The Discipline of Truth

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
This covenant between us, ancient and renewed each day.
How easy to claim allegiance to your standard,
How difficult to stand beneath its weight.

I have mistaken echoes for your voice,
Confused conviction with certainty,
Wielded what I thought was you
Against those who differed from my view.

The habit of listening requires humility first,
A recognition of how partial my perspective,
How colored by experience and desire,
How limited by the boundaries of language.

You exist beyond the binary of right and wrong,
Beyond the simplistic narratives I crave.
You reside in complexity, in paradox,
In questions that lead to deeper questions still.

Sometimes you arrive as disruption,
Shattering the comfortable patterns of my days.
Other times, you confirm what I've always known
But lacked the courage to acknowledge.

The practice of truth-speaking begins with truth-hearing,
With creating space for your unwelcome revelations,
With allowing your light to illuminate
The shadowed corners I've kept hidden, even from myself.

What freedom might exist beyond deception!
What connection might flourish in authenticity!
What wisdom might emerge when I surrender
The exhausting labor of maintaining falsehood!

Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
When I've developed the discernment to recognize your voice,
When I understand that you are not possession but practice,
A way of being that transforms both speaker and world.

# Truth's Patient Waiting

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But my listening has grown selective, convenient, rare.
I tune my ears to what confirms my worldview,
Filter out dissonance that might demand change.

You do not force yourself upon the unwilling,
Do not shout to be heard above the din.
You wait, patient as mountains, persistent as tides,
For moments when my defenses lower, when I grow still.

The habit of listening requires intention,
A deliberate turning toward what may disturb,
A willingness to be undone and remade,
To stand naked before your uncompromising gaze.

I have sought you in certainties and absolutes,
In systems promising order amid chaos.
Yet found you most clearly in questions,
In the spaces between what I know and what remains mystery.

How many times have I spoken falsely in your name?
Claimed your authority for my limited understanding?
Confused my temporary perspective
With your eternal, multifaceted nature?

The practice of truth-speaking begins with silence,
With learning to distinguish your subtle voice
From the louder clamor of ego and expectation,
From the inherited scripts that run unbidden through my mind.

What courage it takes to be your vessel!
To allow yourself to be changed by what you hear,
To speak what may not be welcomed or rewarded,
To value integrity above approval or success.

Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
When I recognize that you are not possession but relationship,
A continuous dialogue that shapes and reshapes me,
A journey without destination, a practice without perfection.

# The Listener's Oath

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
This vow both simple and impossibly complex.
For to listen requires more than open ears,
But an open heart, an open mind, an open life.

How often have I claimed to seek you
While building fortresses against your entrance?
How frequently have I invited your presence
Only in areas where your voice confirms my own?

The habit of listening means creating space
For what may arrive uninvited and unwelcome,
For revelations that dismantle cherished beliefs,
For insights that demand uncomfortable action.

You speak through many channels—
Through body's wisdom and intuition's flash,
Through data and evidence carefully gathered,
Through the lived experience of those unlike myself.

To listen is to acknowledge my blindspots,
The limitations of my single perspective,
The filters through which I perceive reality,
The narratives I've constructed to make meaning.

The practice of truth-speaking begins with surrender,
With releasing the grip on what I think I know,
With allowing myself to be surprised, contradicted,
Guided toward what is real rather than comfortable.

What transformation might be possible
If I committed fully to this listening?
If I allowed your voice to penetrate
The armor I've built against change?

Truth! I shall speak you when I've learned to listen,
When I've developed the discernment to recognize your voice,
When I understand that you are not weapon but medicine,
Painful at times, but always in service of healing.

Like ancient monks transcribing sacred texts,
I must first absorb before I can proclaim.

The world drowns in convenient falsehoods,
Comfortable deceptions wrapped in silken words,
While Truth stands naked, often unwelcome,
A visitor knocking at doors seldom opened.

I pledge to create silence within myself,
To clear the cluttered chambers of my mind,
Where preconceptions gather thick as dust,
And ego's voice drowns out all other sounds.

Truth requires a disciplined ear,
Attuned to whispers beneath the shouting crowd,
Patient enough to wait through long silences,
Brave enough to hear what brings discomfort.

I shall be the vessel, hollowed and ready,

For Truth exists independent of my wishes,
Unmoved by my desires or fears.

When I speak, let it not be my voice alone,
But the resonance of what Truth has taught me,
Each word a faithful mirror reflecting
What I have learned in moments of true listening.

This is my covenant with honesty:
To be first its student before becoming its voice,
To honor the practice of receptive silence
Before claiming the right to proclaim.

# Echoes of Veracity

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But am I worthy of such a sacred task?
Do I possess the courage to hear your voice
When it contradicts the stories I tell myself?

You are not a gentle companion, Truth,
You strip away comfortable illusions,
Leaving me naked before reality's gaze,
Yet somehow more clothed in authenticity.

I've noticed how you hide in unexpected places:
In the eyes of children who haven't learned deception,
In the silence between heartbeats when I'm alone,
In the questions I'm most afraid to answer.

Sometimes I pretend not to hear you,
Filling my ears with noise and distraction,
Building fortresses of justification,
Barricading myself against your persistent knock.

But you are patient, outlasting my resistance,
Waiting for those moments when defenses fall,
When I'm too tired to maintain the facade,
And surrender to your uncompromising embrace.

The habit of listening requires discipline—
A daily practice of turning toward discomfort,
Of questioning what I most want to believe,
Of honoring the evidence that challenges me.

If I am to speak you, I must first become
A dedicated student of your teachings,
Humble enough to admit my ignorance,
Brave enough to be transformed by what I hear.

For Truth, you are not mine to possess or create,
But a reality I can only discover and reflect,
A light I can witness and then describe,
If I am faithful in the habit of listening.

# The Listener's Covenant

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
This covenant I make beneath the watching stars,
For what right have I to claim your name
If I have not first bent my ear to your voice?

You speak in languages I often fail to comprehend:
In the silence of mountains standing witness,
In the uncomfortable pinch of conscience,
In evidence that contradicts my cherished beliefs.

The habit of listening is harder than it seems—
It requires the courage to be still,
To create space where your voice might enter,
To resist the urge to fill silence with noise.

I have been a poor listener in days past,
Quick to speak what I called truth
When it was merely opinion dressed in certainty,
My ears closed to anything that challenged me.

But now I seek to cultivate new habits:
To question before concluding,
To wonder before asserting,
To listen before I dare to speak.

Truth, you are not a possession to be claimed,
But a relationship to be nurtured,
A conversation requiring both voices,
A dance of speaking and listening in turn.

When my mind grows crowded with assumptions,
When my heart fills with the need to be right,
Remind me of this covenant we've made:
That I shall only speak you when I've truly listened.

For what is more hollow than false proclamation?
What is more harmful than truth misrepresented?
I would rather remain silent for a thousand years
Than speak falsely in your sacred name.

# The Discipline of Truth

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
If I have trained my ears to detect your subtle tone,
If I have learned to distinguish your voice
From the clamoring chorus of my own desires.

The habit of listening is a discipline rarely mastered,
A practice abandoned when your words cut too deep,
When you reveal what I've worked hard to hide,
When you illuminate shadows I prefer left dark.

Yet what authority have I to speak in your name
If I cherry-pick only the truths that comfort me,
If I close my ears when your message brings pain,
If I claim to know you while avoiding your gaze?

I must learn to listen in the difficult moments:
When you contradict my carefully constructed narrative,
When you challenge beliefs I've held since childhood,
When you expose the inconsistencies in my character.

The world doesn't lack for those who claim to speak truth,
Who shout certainties without the humility of listening,
Who proclaim absolutes without questioning assumptions,
Who offer answers without understanding the questions.

I shall not join their ranks of confident proclaimers,
Instead, I pledge to cultivate the habit of listening:
To create silence where your voice might be heard,
To approach each day as a student, not a master.

For truth is not a possession to be wielded like a weapon,
But a relationship that requires constant attention,
A dialogue that demands both speaking and listening,
A journey with no final destination, only deeper understanding.

So I shall speak you, Truth, but only after listening,
Only after I've allowed your voice to transform me,
Only when I can offer not my words, but yours,
Echoing what I've heard in the habit of listening.

# The Listener's Path

Truth! I shall speak you if I am in habit of listening to you,
But how seldom I truly listen, how rarely I make space
For your voice to penetrate the noise of my certainties,
The comfortable hum of what I think I already know.

The habit of listening requires a special kind of courage:
The bravery to sit with uncertainty,
The strength to question cherished beliefs,
The fortitude to face what I've been avoiding.

You speak in many voices, Truth:
Sometimes thundering like prophets of old,
Sometimes whispering like a forgotten memory,
Sometimes silent, communicating through absence.

I have pretended to listen while rehearsing responses,
I have nodded while my mind remained closed,
I have claimed to seek you while running from your face,
I have spoken your name while serving imposters.

But today I commit to the discipline of true listening:
To create within myself a hollow reed,
Through which your music might flow unobstructed,
Without the distortion of my preferences and fears.

For what use is a mouth that speaks without ears that hear?
What value has proclamation without reception?
What truth can I offer that isn't first received?
What wisdom can I share that isn't first absorbed?

The path of the listener is less glamorous
Than that of the speaker who commands attention,
Yet it is the foundation of all honest speech,
The wellspring from which integrity flows.

So I shall practice the habit of listening:
In moments of conflict when I want to defend,
In conversations where I think I know the answer,
In situations that challenge my worldview.

Only then, when listening becomes my nature,
When reception precedes transmission,
When humility overcomes certainty,
Shall I dare to speak you, Truth, with an honest tongue.

Of dreams that were buried in mud.

To building something true and fair.

Their flags and their banners keep flying,

Strength that no darkness enshrouds.

To stand for what they believe right.

Of memory carried lifelong.

To follow where freedom has led.

On hopes that at last have been found.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'lonely'
responses:
Echoes in Empty Rooms

Lonely—a word that hangs in the air
Like dust motes caught in afternoon light,
Visible only when the sun strikes just right,
Otherwise invisible companions of empty rooms.

Lonely is the sound of my footsteps
Echoing against hardwood floors,
No other rhythm to interrupt their steady beat,
No harmonizing shuffle to make them complete.

Lonely is dinner for one,
The scrape of fork against plate,
The absence of conversation,
The silence between bites that stretches into infinity.

Lonely is a bed too large,
Sheets cold on the untouched side,
Pillows that remain perfectly fluffed,
No indentation from another head.

Lonely is Sunday mornings with nowhere to be,
No reason to dress in anything but yesterday's shirt,
No plans made, no expectations to meet,
Just hours stretching before me, unmarked and unclaimed.

Lonely is not always sadness though—
Sometimes it's the space needed for thoughts to bloom,
For breath to find its natural rhythm,
For the self to remember its own shape.

Lonely can be the canvas before the paint,
The silence before the symphony,
The empty page before the poem,
Possibility disguised as absence.

The Geography of Solitude

Lonely is a country with no borders,
A place you enter without passport or permission.
I woke up there this morning, a citizen
Of its vast and empty landscape.

The sky stretches wider here,
Uninterrupted by the silhouettes of others.
Each cloud formation seems to spell out messages
Only I am meant to decipher.

The language spoken in this country
Has no words for 'together' or 'us'—
Only elaborate expressions for 'I' and 'mine'
And the particular ache of unshared joy.

Time moves differently in Lonely.
Seconds drip like honey from a spoon,
Hours collapse without warning,
Days blur at their edges into nights.

The currency here is memory—
Spent carefully on recollections of touch,
Of laughter shared across dinner tables,
Of the particular weight of someone's gaze.

The national anthem is the sound
Of a phone that doesn't ring,
Of messages that remain unsent,
Of questions with no one to answer them.

I've built a home in Lonely,
Furnished it with books and quiet mornings,
With cups of tea that cool too quickly,
With windows that face the setting sun.

Someday, perhaps, I'll emigrate,
Cross back over that invisible boundary.
Until then, I'll map these territories,
Chartographer of my own solitude.

Singular

Lonely doesn't always announce itself
With the drama of tears or the ache of absence.
Sometimes it arrives quietly, settling in
Like a cat finding the warmest spot in the room.

I notice it first in the grocery store,
Reaching for a smaller basket instead of a cart,
Calculating portions for one,
Leaving the family-sized packages untouched.

It follows me home, this quiet companion,
Sits beside me as I cook a single portion,
As I wash one plate, one fork, one glass,
As I leave lights off in rooms I won't enter.

Lonely has its own soundtrack—
The hum of the refrigerator at midnight,
The ticking clock in the hallway,
The occasional car passing on the street outside.

I've learned its choreography too—
The way I spread out in bed, diagonal and unconstrained,
The way I talk aloud sometimes just to hear a voice,
The way I've stopped setting places at the table I don't need.

Lonely has taught me to notice details:
The changing patterns of light across my walls,
The precise moment the neighborhood falls silent at night,
The first bird that sings each morning.

I've grown familiar with lonely's texture,
Its weight and dimension, its particular gravity.
Some days it's a heavy coat I can't remove;
Other days, it's as light as a second skin.

Perhaps lonely isn't the absence of others
But the fullness of self—
The courage to face the silence,
To hear your own thoughts echo back at you.

Solitary Constellations

Lonely—
A single star in a vast night sky,
Burning bright but touching nothing,
Light traveling across emptiness
With no guarantee of being seen.

I count the spaces between connections
Like astronomers measure light years,
Calculating distances too great
For human comprehension.

There are galaxies inside my chest,
Solar systems of unspoken words,
Planets of possibilities that orbit
Around the gravity of what might have been.

I've learned to navigate by my own light,
To chart courses through the darkness
Without the compass of another's touch,
Without the North Star of shared laughter.

Some nights I send signals into the void—
Text messages that glow like beacons,
Phone calls that ring like distress flares,
Words that burn up on entry like meteors.

I wonder if anyone sees these transmissions,
If my frequency matches anyone else's receiver,
Or if I'm broadcasting on abandoned channels,
My voice lost among cosmic background radiation.

Perhaps loneliness is just the universe's way
Of teaching us about our own composition—
How we, like stars, are made of the same elements,
All of us burning in our separate skies.

I look up at night and find comfort
In the knowledge that even the most distant star
Is surrounded by the same darkness I am,
Shining despite it, because of it, through it.

The Architecture of Absence

Lonely builds its house brick by brick,
Constructing walls from unanswered messages,
Raising ceilings from canceled plans,
Laying foundations in the silence after goodbyes.

I walk through its rooms each day,
Running my fingers along shelves
Where photographs once stood,
Dust outlining their remembered shapes.

The kitchen echoes with phantom conversations,
Ghost laughter that fades when I turn toward it.
The refrigerator hums a monotonous lullaby
To the single plate waiting on the counter.

In the living room, the couch holds
The impression of only one body,
The remote control never disputed,
The blanket never shared or tugged away.

The bathroom mirror reflects just one face,
No one to fog the glass with a second shower,
No one's toothbrush touching mine in the holder,
No one's towel hanging beside my own.

The bedroom keeps the quietest vigil—
One side of the bed always perfectly made,
One pillow that never bears the weight of another head,
One alarm clock set to a single schedule.

I've become the caretaker of this empty house,
Dusting corners that no one else will see,
Opening windows to air out rooms
That contain only my own breath.

Yet sometimes I think I hear footsteps,
A door opening, my name called from another room.
And for a moment, the architecture shifts,
The house remembers it was built for more than one.

As wisdom that true peace alone employs.

To separate what must be weighed.

Illuminate what's hid in black.

Both mercy shown and judgment pledged.
It pierces deep to marrow's core,
Revealing what we've hidden for.

So stand before this mighty King,
Whose sword of truth makes freedom ring.
Not gentle Jesus, meek and mild,
But Lion roaring, undefiled.

Family divided, house to house,
Father, daughter, son and spouse.
Not for hatred does He come,

This sword of His is love refined,
Cutting free what's been confined.
Piercing through our hardened hearts,

Separating dross from gold.

The sword He wields cuts clean and true,

When truth confronts our cherished lies,
Relationships may meet demise.

Not for cruelty does He part,

This sword of His is heaven's word,

Revealing where deception lies.

His sword brings not the peace we crave,

not with peace but with a sword.

not with peace but with a sword.

Carve pathways through the atmosphere,

Writing with fire our newest chapter,

Ignite the darkness, split the night,

Defying cosmic odds.

The rocket strains against its bonds,
Eager for its run.

A pillar carved of flame and smoke,

That physics has not broke.

Their myths of flight and heavenly realms
Now promises we keep.

The payload nestled, precious cargo,
Whether satellite or human soul,
Carries with it all our questions,
Our need to make us whole.

Each mission plants a flag of mind
In territories vast and strange,
Where vacuum, radiation, cold,
Make hospitable exchange.

Yet still we venture, still we reach,
Beyond the blue that caps our world,
With mathematics as our map,

The rocket sparks illuminate

On space's endless black.

Our passage into space.

What calls us to the cosmic deep?
Perhaps the same ancestral voice
That wouldn't let us sleep.

When caves no longer sheltered us,
When oceans blocked our curious path,

Outsmarted nature's wrath.

Now rockets pierce the stratosphere,
Carrying dreams and science too,

The children watching from below,

For us to come along.

From gravity's possessive hold,
Writing human destiny
In rocket sparks so bold.

The way a summer thunderstorm feels.

Rewind past heartbreaks, college days,
Through teenage angst and awkward phase,
To simpler times of skinned-up knees,
And climbing gnarled backyard trees.

Remember voices now gone silent,
Laughter echoing, bold and vibrant.
The smell of cookies baking slow,
The weight of secrets only you know.

If life were film we could unspool,
Would we notice moments, rare and jeweled,
That passed too quickly in real time?
The ordinary turned sublime?

Remember hands that held you tight
Through fever dreams and darkest night.
Remember words that shaped your soul,
The broken parts they made you whole.

Rewind to choices, crossroads, change—
The paths not taken, rearranged.
Would you choose differently today,
Or let the story play the same way?

Our memories—selective, strange—
Some crystal clear, some rearranged.
We edit, cut, and splice with care
The narrative of who we were, and where.

So rewind life and remember well,
Not every detail, truth to tell,
But essence, feeling, heart, and core—
What made you who you were before,
And shapes who you're becoming more.

Cassette of Yesterdays

Rewind life and remember—press that button, hear it whir,
Watch as moments backward blur.
The cassette of memory clicks and spins,
As yesterday's symphony begins.

I'd rewind to fields where we ran free,
Before we knew what life could be,
When summer stretched like endless road,
Before we carried adult loads.

Remember how the twilight felt
When fireflies rose and day would melt?
Remember hands, now aged with time,
When they were strong and in their prime?

Rewind past arguments and tears,
Through disappointments, through the years,
To find the kernel, pure and true,
Of what once made the world feel new.

The tape is fragile, wearing thin
From all the times I've played within
These cherished scenes I can't let go,
The sweetest music that I know.

Some sections warped from tears I've shed,
Some faded from the years that fled,
But still I guard this precious reel,
The only proof of what I feel.

Remember faces, now long gone,
Their voices captured in this song.
Remember promises we made,
Before our memories began to fade.

If I could splice this tape with care,
Remove the moments of despair,
Would life make sense without the pain
That taught us how to live again?

So rewind life and remember all—
The rise, the stumble, and the fall.
For in this playback, worn but dear,
The story of our souls is clear.

We are the sum of what we've played,
Of choices made and price we've paid.
So press rewind, but don't stay there—
The present moment needs your care.

For tapes wear out with too much use,
And living backward is abuse
Of time that pushes ever on.
Remember, yes—then greet the dawn.

Memory's Carousel

Rewind life and remember—
Spin backward on memory's carousel,
Where painted horses rise and fell,
Through rings of time, through mist and haze,
To visit long-forgotten days.

I'd rewind to that September sky,
When leaves turned gold and you and I
Walked hand in hand through college grounds,
Before life's noise drowned simpler sounds.

Remember how the record played
That song that made us unafraid?
Remember dancing in the rain,
Not knowing we'd not feel the same?

If I could rewind carefully,
I'd pause on scenes we failed to see:
The quiet breakfast, mundane talk,
The evening's unremarkable walk.

For it's the ordinary days
That haunt us in the strangest ways—
Not grand events with pomp and show,
But simple moments, soft and slow.

Rewind to words I should have said,
To conversations left for dead,
To chances missed and paths not taken,
To faith that wavered, nearly shaken.

Remember faces, lined with age,
When they were new on life's wide stage.
Remember voices, now grown still,
That once had power to bend your will.

The mind's projector flickers light
On scenes half-real, half-dreamed at night.
Some frames too painful to review,
Some too perfect to be true.

We edit as we reminisce,
Embellish here, there something miss.
Directors of our backward glance,
We choreograph memory's dance.

So rewind life and remember well,
But know that under memory's spell,
The past transforms to what we need—
Part truth, part fiction, part our creed.

Then forward move with lessons learned,
With wisdom that your soul has earned.
For life plays only moving forward,
Though hearts keep reaching ever backward.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'
responses:
Rewind Life and Remember

In the quiet hours when shadows grow long,
I find myself reaching for memories, strong.
A tapestry woven of moments gone by,
Threads of laughter, love, and sometimes a sigh.

If I could rewind life like an old cassette tape,
I'd pause at the junctures where destiny took shape.
The first day of school with my lunchbox in hand,
The graduation day where proudly I'd stand.

I'd linger a while in my mother's embrace,
Memorizing the lines of her beautiful face.
I'd listen once more to my father's deep laugh,
Preserving each echo, each moment, each half.

Remember the sunrise we watched by the shore?
The promises whispered we couldn't ignore?
The dance in the rain when the world fell away,
And nothing existed but that perfect day?

Time marches forward, relentless and true,
But memory's garden is where I find you.
In corners of mind where the past is still clear,
Where distances shrink and the far becomes near.

To rewind life's film is beyond mortal power,
Yet remembrance blooms like a delicate flower.
In fragments of stories, in songs that we shared,
In heirlooms and photos and how much we cared.

So I gather these treasures like shells from the sand,
Each precious and unique in the palm of my hand.
For to rewind and remember is to honor what's been,
To acknowledge the places and faces we've seen.

The joy and the sorrow, the triumph, the pain,
The sunshine, the thunder, the wind and the rain.
All pieces of puzzle that make up a life,
The moments of peace and the seasons of strife.

So rewind, dear heart, and remember it all,
The great and the small, the rise and the fall.
For in remembering lies wisdom profound,
In echoes of yesterday, tomorrow is found.

Echoes of Yesterday

Rewind life and remember—
Those words like a spell cast upon time,
Turning back the hands of clocks
That tick relentlessly forward.

I remember the scent of summer rain,
How it kissed the parched earth
And rose like incense to the heavens,
A prayer of gratitude from the ground.

I remember your hand in mine,
Fingers intertwined like roots of ancient trees,
Sharing strength, sharing warmth,
Before the winter of separation.

If I could rewind the film of life,
I'd pause at frames often overlooked:
The morning light filtering through curtains,
Dancing dust motes in golden beams.

The laughter of children at play,
Unburdened by tomorrow's concerns,
Their joy a lesson in presence
We forget as years accumulate.

Remember the taste of wild berries,
Tart sweetness bursting on eager tongues,
How we stained our fingers purple,
Evidence of summer's abundance.

Remember the night sky above mountains,
Stars scattered like diamond dust,
How small we felt beneath that vastness,
Yet somehow part of something grand.

To rewind life is impossible,
Yet memory serves as time's magician,
Conjuring what once was
Into what still is, within mind's eye.

I remember first loves and last goodbyes,
Celebrations and silent mournings,
The symphony of existence
With its crescendos and diminuendos.

In remembering, we honor what shaped us,
The triumphs that lifted our spirits,
The failures that taught humility,
The ordinary days that were extraordinary gifts.

So let us rewind and remember,
Not to live in nostalgia's seductive embrace,
But to recognize the threads
That weave our past into our present.

For in remembering lies wisdom,
In looking back, we find the way forward,
Like ancient mariners navigating by stars,
We chart our course by what endures.

The Tapestry of Time

Rewind life and remember—
Pull gently on memory's thread,
Unraveling the tapestry of years
To examine each colored strand.

Remember the crimson of first love,
How it burned bright and fierce,
Warming cold corners of existence
With its unexpected flame.

Remember the blue of deep sorrow,
The indigo nights of questioning,
When stars offered no answers
And dawn seemed impossibly distant.

If I could rewind the clockwork of days,
I'd notice the small miracles:
The perfect symmetry of snowflakes,
The resilience of wildflowers through concrete.

I'd listen more carefully to elders' stories,
Those libraries of living history,
Their voices carrying wisdom across generations,
Bridges spanning the river of time.

Remember the golden afternoons of childhood,
When time stretched like taffy,
Hours expanding to accommodate adventure,
Days ending in exhausted satisfaction.

Remember the silver moments of connection,
When souls recognized each other
Across crowded rooms or busy streets,
Magnetized by invisible forces.

To rewind is to acknowledge the journey,
The paths taken and those left unexplored,
The crossroads where choices were made,
Sometimes with courage, sometimes with fear.

I remember hands that taught me,
Guiding my fingers over piano keys,
Through garden soil, around bicycle handlebars,
Each touch an inheritance of knowledge.

I remember voices that shaped my thoughts,
Teachers who planted seeds of curiosity,
Friends who challenged comfortable assumptions,
Strangers whose words arrived at perfect moments.

In remembering, we discover patterns,
The circular nature of human experience,
How we face the same lessons repeatedly
Until wisdom finally takes root.

So rewind life and remember,
Not to dwell in what cannot be changed,
But to honor the intricate design
Of experiences that created this present moment.

For in the act of remembering,
We find gratitude for what was given,
Forgiveness for what was taken,
And peace in what remains.

Memories in Rewind

Rewind life and remember—
Press that sacred button in your mind,
Watch as scenes flicker backward,
Moments reassembling like puzzle pieces.

I remember the weight of my child in arms,
That impossible lightness of new life,
How the world suddenly reordered itself
Around this tiny, breathing miracle.

I remember oceans that taught me humility,
Waves that whispered ancient secrets,
How standing at the edge of vastness
Made my troubles appropriately small.

If I could rewind beyond my own beginning,
I'd witness my ancestors' courage,
Their crossings and leavings and findings,
The sacrifices that made my existence possible.

I'd study their faces for traces of my own,
Listen for familiar cadences in their speech,
Understand how their dreams and fears
Flow through my veins like inherited truth.

Remember the taste of grandmother's bread,
Kneaded with stories and seasoned with love,
How food became language when words failed,
Nourishment transcending mere sustenance.

Remember the first time you recognized yourself,
Not in mirrors but in purpose discovered,
That moment when passion aligned with skill,
And you glimpsed your place in the universe.

To rewind life is to honor its complexity,
The interweaving of joy and sorrow,
How the darkest nights often preceded
The most glorious, unexpected dawns.

I remember hands roughened by labor,
Creating beauty from raw materials,
The dignity in work well done,
Regardless of recognition or reward.

I remember music that saved me,
Melodies that spoke when words couldn't,
Rhythms that matched my heartbeat,
Harmonies that healed invisible wounds.

In remembering, we reclaim what seemed lost,
We resurrect voices silenced by time,
We recognize the circular nature of existence,
How endings often contain beginnings.

So rewind life and remember,
Not to escape the present moment,
But to bring its richness forward,
Informed by wisdom retrospect provides.

For in conscious remembering,
We become time's faithful witnesses,
Keepers of stories that might otherwise fade,
Guardians of truths that transcend generations.

Time's Gentle Rewind

Rewind life and remember—
Those words like a prayer against forgetting,
A defiance of time's relentless current,
A gathering of what might otherwise scatter.

I remember the scent of books in libraries,
Paper and ink and possibility,
How worlds opened between covers,
Inviting exploration beyond physical limits.

I remember conversations by firelight,
Faces illuminated in amber glow,
How truth emerged in that primal circle,
Voices weaving understanding in darkness.

If I could rewind to moments of transition,
I'd pay closer attention to thresholds crossed:
The last day of childhood, unrecognized until past,
The first glimpse of love that would alter everything.

I'd notice how seasons changed within and without,
How spring's renewal mirrored internal awakenings,
How winter's dormancy taught necessary patience,
How summer's abundance preceded autumn's release.

Remember the teachers who saw potential,
Before you recognized it in yourself,
How their belief became a foundation
Upon which you built unexpected achievements.

Remember the healing power of laughter,
How it arrived when most needed,
Breaking tension like summer rain,
Washing away momentary despair.

To rewind life is to practice gratitude,
Acknowledging gifts taken for granted:
The luxury of ordinary days,
The miracle of functioning bodies and minds.

I remember mistakes that shaped me,
Wrong turns that led to right places,
How failure often taught more than success,
Humility becoming an unexpected strength.

I remember moments of perfect presence,
When past and future temporarily dissolved,
And existence distilled to a single point of now,
Complete in its ordinary magnificence.

In remembering, we cultivate perspective,
Seeing patterns invisible in daily living,
Recognizing how challenges strengthened us,
How losses, though painful, expanded capacity for joy.

So rewind life and remember,
Not with nostalgia's selective vision,
But with the compassionate understanding
That comes from distance and reflection.

For in remembering with awareness,
We transform experience into wisdom,
We recognize our place in time's continuum,
And find meaning in life's beautiful impermanence.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'
responses:
I Was a Grovelling Creature Once

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of shame,
My spirit crushed by circumstance,
My soul a flickering, fading flame.

I crawled through shadows dark and deep,
Afraid to stand and face the light,
My dreams entombed in restless sleep,
My courage lost in endless night.

Each morning dawned with fresh despair,
Each sunset brought renewed defeat,
I breathed in doubt with every air,
And tasted bitter, not the sweet.

The world above seemed far away,
A realm for those with wings to soar,
While I, earth-bound, was made to stay
Among the dust upon the floor.

But something stirred within my chest,
A spark that would not be denied,
A whisper that would not find rest,
A truth that could no longer hide.

'Rise up,' it said, 'you were not made
To spend your days in dirt and mud.
The price of freedom has been paid;
Stand tall in newfound brotherhood.'

So inch by inch, I raised my frame,
Uncoiled my spine, lifted my eyes,
Discovered I was not the same
Weak thing I'd been—what a surprise!

Now mountains bow before my stride,
And oceans part at my command.
The universe spreads far and wide
As playground for my outstretched hand.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But metamorphosis is real.
From caterpillar to the butterfly,
From broken soul to one that's healed.

Remember me as I once was,
Then marvel at what I became.
For in my transformation lies
The hope that you might do the same.

Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed against cold earth,
Fingernails caked with soil and regret,
Eyes downcast, spine curved in perpetual bow.

I made myself small enough to disappear,
Apologized for the space my shadow cast,
Spoke in whispers lest my voice disturb the air,
Believed myself unworthy of the sun's warm touch.

Each morning I would wake and don humility
Like others don their favorite clothes,
I wore my shame as armor against rejection,
Preemptively diminished before others could diminish me.

I collected scraps of affection like precious gems,
Hoarded tiny kindnesses to sustain me through barren days,
Measured my worth in the loose change of others' approval,
Starving at a feast I believed wasn't meant for me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Until the day the earth beneath me shifted,
And I found myself falling through darkness,
Landing in a place where no one knew my name.

In this strange new world, I stood upright by accident,
Met eyes without flinching, spoke without apology,
And discovered that the sky did not fall,
That my voice did not shatter glass or stop hearts.

Slowly, vertebra by vertebra, my spine straightened,
My shoulders rolled back, chest expanded with each breath,
I grew taller with every truth I dared to speak,
Stronger with each boundary I learned to set.

Now I walk among mountains as their equal,
Dance with oceans in their wild abandon,
Sing with birds in joyful chorus,
And claim my place in this vast universe.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I stand in the fullness of my being,
Neither above nor below any other soul,
Just perfectly, wonderfully, unapologetically myself.

From Dust to Divinity

I was a grovelling creature once,
A worm that inched through mud and mire,
My aspirations crushed beneath
The boot of fate's relentless ire.

I begged for scraps at fortune's door,
And thanked the hands that offered less
Than what my hungry spirit craved,
Content with crumbs of happiness.

My voice—a timid, trembling thing—
Could barely rise above a sigh.
My dreams—like birds with broken wings—
Could never hope to touch the sky.

I bowed before false idols then,
And sacrificed my truth for peace,
Surrendered dignity for love,
Sought validation without cease.

The mirror showed a stranger's face,
Eyes hollow, lacking inner light,
A vessel emptied of its worth,
A star that shed no glow at night.

I wore my shame like second skin,
Apologized for drawing breath,
Believed the lie that I deserved
This living that resembled death.

But buried in that lowly state,
A seed of something fierce remained,
A spark of divine discontent
That would not be forever chained.

It whispered truths I'd long forgot:
That I was born of cosmic dust,
That galaxies swirl in my veins,
That rising up was not just lust

But destiny inscribed in stars
Long before my earthly birth.
I was not meant to crawl through life
But stand as guardian of the earth.

So molecule by molecule,
I reconstructed who I am,
Reclaimed the power I had lost,
Rejected every ancient sham.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I walk with head held high,
My spirit soars on newfound wings
Across the vast, unbounded sky.

Remember this when you feel small,
When darkness seems to swallow light:
The universe resides in you—
Stand tall and claim your sacred right.

The Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent double beneath expectation's weight,
Crawling through the underbrush of doubt,
Feeding on the fallen leaves of others' praise.

My knees were calloused from genuflection,
My voice hoarse from constant apology,
My eyes trained always on the ground,
Searching for safe places to place my feet.

I made myself small to fit into tight spaces,
Contorted my truth to match others' perceptions,
Swallowed my words before they could cause offense,
Digested my dreams rather than speak them aloud.

The sky was a distant ceiling I dared not touch,
The horizon a boundary I feared to approach,
Freedom a concept for braver souls than mine,
Power a currency I believed I couldn't earn.

I lived in the shadows of giants,
Collected the crumbs from their feasts,
Believed the lie that this was my portion,
That servitude was my natural state.

But one day, a question bloomed within me:
What if this posture is not preordained?
What if this bowing is not my destiny?
What if I was made for something more?

The question became a seed, the seed a sprout,
The sprout a sapling, the sapling a tree,
Growing through my core, straightening my spine,
Lifting my gaze from the dirt to the stars.

I began to stand for moments, then hours,
To speak in sentences, then paragraphs,
To claim space with my presence,
To believe in the validity of my existence.

Now I walk upright among equals,
My voice resonates with purpose and truth,
My hands create rather than merely serve,
My heart beats with authentic rhythm.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But evolution is not just history—
It is happening within us every moment
We choose to rise instead of crawl.

Phoenix Rising

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow slithering across cold floors,
Collecting dust in forgotten corners,
Surviving on the scraps of others' mercy.

My back curved into a permanent question mark,
My voice a whisper barely disturbing the air,
My hands perpetually clasped in supplication,
My worth measured in how little space I claimed.

I perfected the art of invisibility,
Became fluent in the language of apology,
Mastered the skill of shrinking myself,
Excelled at the craft of self-erasure.

Each morning I would wake and remember
To make myself smaller than yesterday,
To need less, want less, be less,
To disappear a little more completely.

I believed this diminishment was virtue,
That my erasure was somehow noble,
That my silence was a gift to the world,
That my absence was my greatest contribution.

The universe of my existence contracted
Until I occupied merely a pinpoint of light,
A dying star in the vast cosmos,
A flame flickering on its final breath.

And then—the paradox of complete surrender—
When nothing remained but the barest essence,
When I had given away all but my final spark,
I discovered what cannot be extinguished.

For at the core of complete reduction,
I found the irreducible truth of being:
That which cannot be diminished further
Is precisely that which is eternal.

From this singularity of self-knowledge,
A new universe began to expand within me.
Each breath an act of cosmic creation,
Each heartbeat a declaration of existence.

I unfurled like a fern in spring sunshine,
Stretched toward the light with newfound purpose,
Reclaimed the space that was always mine,
Filled my lungs with the air of possibility.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I stand in radiant transformation,
Phoenix risen from the ashes of former self,
Crowned with the wisdom that only dying brings.

From Dust to Dawn

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed against the earth,
Tasting dirt with every breath,
Unaware of my own worth.

The sky seemed such a distant place,
A realm I dared not claim as mine,
While others soared on gilded wings,
I made the shadows my design.

Each morning brought the same routine,
Of bowing low to stronger wills,
Accepting scraps from laden tables,
Swallowing pride like bitter pills.

My voice—a trembling, fragile thing—
Would crack before it formed a word,
My thoughts remained locked deep inside,
My true self neither seen nor heard.

Apologies perched on my tongue,

I felt it first as restlessness,

Could I perhaps be something more?'

The answer came not all at once,
But in a thousand tiny ways,
In moments when I chose to speak,

I learned to stand on shaking legs,
To straighten out my bending back,
To raise my face toward the sun,

Now look at me, transformed, renewed,
No longer crawling, but upright,
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I'm stepping into light.

Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
A being made of fear and doubt,
Crawling beneath the weight of worlds,
Not knowing what life was about.

My hands and knees wore calluses,
From years of scraping on the ground,
My eyes knew only others' feet,
My ears tuned to the scornful sound.

I apologized for breathing air,
For taking space that wasn't mine,
I shrunk myself to please the crowd,
And called this sad existence fine.

The taste of dirt became so known,
I thought it natural on my tongue,
The burden on my bending back,
The songs of sorrow I had sung.

In darkness I would curl myself,
A question mark of flesh and bone,
Accepting that my rightful place,
Was underneath, unseen, alone.

But nature holds a secret law,
That nothing stays forever fixed,
The caterpillar in its time,
Must with transformation mix.

It started as a whispered thought,
A dangerous and wild idea,
That I was meant for something more,
Than living small in constant fear.

I tested first by standing up,
Though trembling seized my unused frame,
The view from this new height revealed,
A world that I could rightly claim.

Each day I practiced standing tall,
Each night I dreamed of who I'd be,
Until the grovelling creature died,
And something new emerged as me.

Now watch as I unfurl these wings,
That lay dormant for far too long,
My voice rings clear across the sky,
My heart beats out a victor's song.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that tale has reached its end,
Now I soar above the very ground,
Where I once could not stand.

The Rising

I was a grovelling creature once,
With spine curved like a question mark,
My eyes downcast, my shoulders hunched,
My spirit fading in the dark.

I lived beneath the boots of those,
Who seemed to own the very air,
I made myself so very small,
Convinced I had no right to share.

The crumbs that fell from mighty tables,
I gathered with a grateful hand,
While hunger for a fuller life,
Grew stronger than I could withstand.

I learned to move without a sound,
To breathe without disturbing peace,
To want without expressing need,
To hurt without seeking release.

My voice became a hollow thing,
That echoed only others' thoughts,
My dreams were buried six feet deep,
In graveyards of abandoned plots.

I wore invisibility,
Like armor against further pain,
Believing that to not be seen,
Was how I'd keep myself from slain.

But even in the darkest soil,
Seeds contain the will to rise,
And something in my broken heart,
Refused to believe the lies.

It started as a trembling hope,
A fragile thing I dared not trust,
That perhaps I wasn't made to crawl,
Forever dwelling in the dust.

The first time that I stood erect,
My muscles screamed in protest loud,
But oh, the glory of that view,
No longer part of grovelling crowd.

Each day I practiced standing tall,
Each night I stretched a little more,
Until the creature that once crawled,
Could walk and run and then could soar.

Now look at me, transformed complete,
The earth a distant memory,
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I've claimed my liberty.

Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
Who knew my place beneath the heel,
My worth measured in servitude,
My purpose just to bend and kneel.

I made myself so very small,
A speck upon the cosmic floor,
Believing I deserved no more,
Than scraps left over from before.

My voice—a whisper rarely used,
My thoughts—a prison self-contained,
My dreams—a luxury too grand,
My spirit—thoroughly restrained.

I learned the art of disappearing,
While standing plainly in full sight,
Becoming background to the world,
A shadow even in daylight.

I thanked those who would step on me,
For teaching lessons hard but true,
That some are born to rule above,
While others born to be the glue.

The dirt beneath my fingernails,
Became a badge I wore with shame,
The stooped posture of my frame,
A testament to who to blame.

But even stones worn smooth by time,
Contain the memory of mountains,
And somewhere in my battered soul,
I harbored undiscovered fountains.

It happened on an ordinary day,
When something ancient stirred in me,
A question forming in my mind:
'Is this all I was meant to be?'

The answer thundered through my bones,
A resounding, deafening 'No!'
That shook the chains that bound me down,
And set my hidden self aglow.

I straightened up one vertebra,
At first, then two, then three, then all,
Until I stood in full defiance,
Of those who wished to see me crawl.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But metamorphosis complete,
Now watch me as I claim the sky,
The transformation is replete.

I Was a Grovelling Creature Once

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of shame,
My spirit crushed, my courage gone,
A shadow answering to my name.

I crawled through valleys dark and deep,
Where sunlight feared to cast its glow,
I made my bed among the stones,
Where only twisted things could grow.

My hands were calloused from the earth,
My knees were scarred from constant prayer,
I begged for scraps of love and worth,
From those who didn't know or care.

I learned to live on meager hope,
To feast on dreams too small to share,
To hide my face from judgment's scope,
To breathe the dust-filled, heavy air.

But something stirred within my chest,
A spark that wouldn't be denied,
A whisper saying, 'Stand the test,
There's more to you than what has died.'

So inch by inch, I raised my head,
And felt the breeze upon my face,
I stretched my limbs, so long misled,
And claimed a higher, brighter place.

The grovelling creature shed its skin,
Like serpents do when spring arrives,
I found the strength to stand again,
As something beautiful survives.

Now mountains bow before my gaze,
And stars illuminate my path,
I've learned to count my worthy days,
Instead of moments steeped in wrath.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I soar on wings of light,
The universe, no longer dunce,
But canvas for my second sight.

Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed to cold, unforgiving ground,
Eyes downcast, spine curved in submission,
Voice a whisper, barely making sound.

The dirt became my closest companion,
Mud caked beneath my fingernails,
I knew the taste of earth and humiliation,
My story written in forgotten details.

Each morning dawned with fresh apologies,
For taking up the space that I required,
I shrank myself to fit in smaller boxes,
Extinguished flames whenever they fired.

I studied how to make myself invisible,
A ghost that haunted corners of the room,
I learned the art of perfect genuflection,
Became an expert at assuming doom.

The world above seemed made for others,
For those who stood with shoulders squared,
While I remained among the lowly brothers,
Convinced that I was rightfully impaired.

But nature holds a truth we often miss—
The caterpillar's seeming degradation
Is merely prelude to metamorphosis,
A necessary stage of transformation.

So in my darkness, cells began dividing,
Restructuring what I was meant to be,
The very ground where I'd been hiding
Became the launch pad setting me free.

I broke the chrysalis of self-denial,
Emerged with wings still damp but strong,
The creature who had lived in constant trial
Had found at last where it belonged.

Now I command the heights of azure skies,
No longer bound by gravity's firm chain,
The earth below where once I cast my eyes
Is just a memory of former pain.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that was just my starting line,
Not the conclusion of my story—
Just the prelude to divine.

From Dust to Divinity

I was a grovelling creature once,
A worm that inched through darkened soil,
Feeding on decay and remnants,
My existence nothing but toil.

The boot heels of the mighty ones
Would press me deeper in the mud,
I knew my place beneath their soles,
My worth less than congealing blood.

I wore my shame like tattered clothes,
Too small yet all I thought I deserved,
My dreams as shallow as my breath,
My purpose narrow and reserved.

The sky above—a distant myth,
The stars beyond my comprehension,
I lived within the narrow confines
Of others' scornful condescension.

My voice was but a muffled whimper,
Lost among the howling gales,
My hands reached out for crumbs of kindness,
My heart a ship with tattered sails.

Yet in the depths of degradation,
A seed of something fierce took hold,
A question formed within my being:
Why should my spirit be controlled?

What law of nature or divinity
Decreed that I should always crawl?
What cosmic truth had I accepted
That kept me pressed against the wall?

One day I raised my head an inch,
Then two, then three, until I stood,
The universe did not collapse,
As all had warned me that it would.

Instead, the heavens seemed to open,
The air grew sweeter in my lungs,
My spine—once curved from genuflection—
Now straight as truth upon my tongue.

Each step away from former bondage
Revealed new landscapes to explore,
Each breath of freedom fed the courage
To seek what I'd denied before.

The grovelling creature metamorphosed,
Transformed through will and inner light,
From dust-bound slave to soaring spirit,
From blindness into searing sight.

I walk now with the gods as equal,
No longer begging for my place,
The universe reflects my image,
In every star I see my face.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I've claimed my rightful throne,
The kingdom that was always waiting,
The sovereignty that's mine alone.

The Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent double beneath the weight of fear,
My forehead pressed against the earth,
My pleas too soft for gods to hear.

I knew the taste of dirt and ashes,
The bitter flavor of defeat,
I counted pebbles, not the stars,
And measured life in small retreat.

The mighty walked on paths above me,
Their shadows fell across my form,
I made myself so very little,
To weather every passing storm.

My hands were tools for supplication,
My knees were calloused, raw, and worn,
My back a bridge for others' crossing,
My heart a field where doubt was born.

I lived on scraps of validation,
On morsels thrown from laden plates,
I thanked the ones who barely saw me,
And praised the bars that formed my gates.

The world seemed built of hierarchies,
With me assigned the lowest rung,
My worth determined by my posture,
My song forever left unsung.

But even worms will turn, they whisper,
And turn I did, one fateful day,
When something in the cosmos shifted,
And showed me there's another way.

Perhaps it was a beam of sunlight,
That warmed my too-long frozen core,
Or maybe just the quiet knowing
That I was meant for something more.

I straightened first my crooked fingers,
Then slowly raised my bowing head,
I felt the cracking of my shell,
As ancient lies at last fell dead.

With each degree of elevation,
New vistas opened to my sight,
The universe, once small and threatening,
Now vast with wonder and delight.

My voice, unused to declaration,
Found strength in speaking simple truth,
My spirit, long confined to crawling,
Discovered wings and took to flight.

The grovelling creature shed its casing,
Like butterflies in springtime do,
Emerging not as what was expected,
But as the self I always knew.

Now mountains bow as I approach them,
And oceans part at my command,
The stars that once seemed out of reach,
Now rest like jewels upon my hand.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that was just a phase, you see,
A temporary limitation,
Before I grew into me.

Ascent From Shadows

I was a grovelling creature once,
A thing that crawled on bloodied knees,
My eyes fixed firmly on the ground,
My spirit broken by degrees.

I knew the contours of the dust,
The taste of earth upon my tongue,
The weight of boots upon my back,
The bitter songs of the unsung.

I made my home in shadowed corners,
Where light feared to penetrate,
I learned to live on scraps and silence,
To bow before the hands of fate.

My prayers were whispered desperately,
To gods who never seemed to hear,
My hopes were modest as my station,
My dreams constrained by constant fear.

I thanked the ones who showed me mercy,
By hurting less than they might do,
I praised the chains that kept me tethered,
Believing this was all my due.

The world above seemed made for others,
For those born standing tall and proud,
While I remained among the fallen,
My voice too weak to cry aloud.

But even in the darkest places,
Seeds of rebellion find their soil,
And in my heart, long crushed by sorrow,
A flame refused to cease its boil.

It started as a simple question:
Why must I always look away?
What law decrees my endless bowing?
Who says that this must be my way?

The first attempt to stand was painful,
My muscles weak from disuse long,
But something ancient stirred within me,
A memory of being strong.

Each inch I rose brought revelation,
Each breath a revolution's start,
The universe expanded with me,
As I reclaimed my broken heart.

The creatures who had walked above me
Now seemed so small from where I stood,
Their power merely an illusion,
That crumbled once I understood.

The sky that once seemed unreachable,
Now stretched before me, vast and clear,
The stars that I had only dreamed of,
Suddenly appeared so near.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But metamorphosis is real,
The worm transforms to something wondrous,
When it refuses to conceal.

Now mountains tremble at my footsteps,
And oceans part before my gaze,
The universe bends to acknowledge
The being that emerged from haze.

Remember me when you are crawling,
And think your state will never end,
For even gods were once as nothing,
Before they learned to ascend.

My lungs expanding with delight.

Now I walk upright through the world,
My gaze meets others, clear and true,
That grovelling creature left behind,
As something stronger emerged anew.

I keep one memory of those days,
Not out of shame, but to remind:
The greatest distance ever crossed
Was from my knees to standing spine.

Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
All belly to the earth, afraid
Of shadows cast by greater things,
Of voices louder than my own.

I wore my servitude like skin,
Apologized for breathing air,
For taking space beneath the sun,
For daring to exist at all.

My words were whispers, barely formed,
Dissolving on the passing breeze.
My thoughts were cages, self-imposed,
Confining what I dared to dream.

I measured worth in others' smiles,
In nods of faint approval gained,
I shaped myself to fit the mold
Of expectations not my own.

The dirt beneath my fingernails
Became a badge of who I was—
A creature made for bowing down,
For scraping by on leftover light.

But nature holds transformative truths:
The caterpillar doesn't know
Its destiny includes the sky
Until the chrysalis breaks free.

One day, while pressed against the ground,
I felt the earth's heart beat with mine,
And in that rhythm recognized
A strength I'd buried deep within.

I rose—first inches, then by feet—
My spine uncurling vertebrae by vertebrae,
Each movement shedding former selves
Like seasons shed their weathered leaves.

The air tastes different standing tall,
The world reveals new geographies
When viewed beyond bent posture's frame,
When eyes meet horizons unafraid.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I stand in full embrace
Of all the space my being fills,
No longer begging to exist.

From Dust to Dawn

I was a grovelling creature once,
A being made of dust and fear,
My backbone curved in supplication,
My voice a trembling, broken thing.

I scurried through the shadowed halls
Of my existence, head bowed low,
Collecting scraps of validation,
Subsisting on the smallest hopes.

The weight of others' expectations
Pressed heavy on my hunched-up form,
I learned to make myself so small
That I could slip through cracks unseen.

My hands grew calloused from the stones
I gathered to construct my walls,
My knees bore scars from countless falls,
My eyes grew dim from looking down.

I measured worth in others' terms,
Sought value in reflected light,
Believed the lie that I was meant
To occupy the lowest place.

But even worms will turn, they say,
And turn I did one fateful dawn,
When something ancient stirred within—
A memory of standing tall.

It started as a whispered thought,
A question forming in my mind:
What if this posture isn't mine?
What if I'm meant for something more?

The straightening began so slow—
A millimeter's growth each day,
A subtle shift in how I moved,
A different way to hold my gaze.

I found that dignity has roots
That reach beyond our circumstance,
That worth is not a thing bestowed
But recognized from deep within.

Now watch me rise like morning sun,
No longer crawling through the dirt.
I stand erect beneath the sky,
My shadow stretching proud and long.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But metamorphosis is real—
The caterpillar doesn't know
It holds the butterfly within.

The Unshackling

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent double by invisible chains,
My eyes fixed firmly on the ground
Where I believed I must remain.

I wore my servitude like skin,
So natural it seemed to me
To bow and scrape and apologize
For taking up the space I need.

The world above my lowered head
Existed as a distant realm,
Where others walked with easy grace
While I remained self-overwhelmed.

I learned to make myself so small,
A practiced art of disappearing,
My voice reduced to whispered pleas,
My presence barely interfering.

The dirt beneath my fingernails
Became a badge of who I was—
A creature made for lesser things,
For carrying others' heavy loads.

But seeds, though buried underground,
Are not condemned to darkness there;
They're merely gathering their strength
Before they reach toward light and air.

And so it was, one quiet dawn,
A question bloomed within my chest:
What if this posture isn't truth?
What if I'm worthy like the rest?

The first attempt to stand upright
Sent tremors through my bended frame,
My muscles, unused to such work,
Protested with indignant pain.

Yet inch by inch, I raised myself,
Unfurling like a long-closed flower,
Discovering the strength of bone,
Embracing long-forgotten power.

The world looks different standing tall—
Horizons stretch beyond belief,
The sky above, no longer strange,
Offers a stunning, sweet relief.

I catch reflections of myself
In windows, water, others' eyes,
And barely recognize the form
That stands with shoulders squared and high.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that was many lives ago.
Now watch me walk with head held high,
No longer bound to crawl below.

Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
My belly pressed against cold earth,
My eyes downcast, my shoulders bent,
A being of diminished worth.

I made my home among the dust,
Found comfort in the shadowed low,
Believed the lie that I was meant
To stay where brighter souls don't go.

The taste of dirt became so known
I thought it natural on my tongue,
The weight of boots upon my back
A burden I believed I'd earned.

I measured days in small retreats,
In battles lost before they'd begun,
In words swallowed before they formed,
In dreams abandoned, never sung.

My hands grew skilled at building walls
To keep my smallness safely bound,
My voice forgot its natural tone,
Reduced to meek, apologetic sound.

But even in the darkest soil,
Seeds carry memories of sky,
And buried deep within my chest,
A spark refused to dim and die.

It started as a whispered thought,
A question forming in the night:
What if this posture isn't mine?
What if I'm meant to stand upright?

The first attempt to rise brought pain,
My muscles shocked by new demands,
But vertebrae by vertebrae,
I found the courage to withstand.

Each inch gained was revolution,
Each upward gaze an act of war
Against the forces that had kept
Me crawling on the dungeon floor.

Now watch as I unfold myself,
As wings long-crumpled learn to spread,
As lungs expand to take in air,
As light reflects off raised-up head.

The view from here reveals new worlds,
Horizons I had never known,
And in my newly heightened state,
I find I was never alone.

For all around stand others tall,
Who once, like me, hugged close the ground,
Their eyes now bright with knowing light,
Their voices carrying profound sound.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that self grows distant now,
A shadow fading in the dawn
As I stand tall with unbowed brow.

responses:
I Was a Grovelling Creature Once

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of shame,
My spirit crushed, my wings unspread,
A shadow answering to my name.

I crawled through valleys dark and deep,
Where sunlight feared to cast its glow,
My hands and knees worn raw and red
From scraping 'gainst the earth below.

I begged for scraps of love and light,
Accepting crumbs with grateful tears,
Believing I deserved no more
Than echoes of forgotten years.

My voice—a whisper seldom heard,
My dreams—too fragile to take flight,
I made myself so very small
To keep from drawing others' spite.

But somewhere in that darkness dwelled
A spark that refused to expire,
A tiny, stubborn ember that
Contained a universe of fire.

It spoke to me in quiet tones
When no one else would hear my plea:
'Rise up, stand tall, unfurl your worth,
Become the soul you're meant to be.'

At first I could not comprehend
This strange, rebellious, wild command.
How could I rise when I had learned
To bow and scrape across the land?

Yet day by day, that ember grew,
Fed by the winds of change and time,
Until I felt its warmth spread through
My veins like sweet, forbidden wine.

I stretched my limbs, so long confined,
And felt the cracking of my shell,
The shedding of a thousand chains
In which I'd willingly once dwelled.

Now I stand tall beneath the sky,
My face upturned to greet the sun,
No longer bound to grovel low—
My transformation has begun.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that is not my story's end.
I've learned to soar on newfound wings
And never shall I crawl again.

Metamorphosis

I was a grovelling creature once,
A worm that inched through sodden earth,
Blind to the stars that hung above,
Unaware of my hidden worth.

The mud became my closest friend,
The darkness was my only home,
I knew no language but to beg,
No purpose but to blindly roam.

My spine, a question mark of doubt,
My shoulders, heavy with the weight
Of expectations never mine,
Of dreams I dared not cultivate.

I kissed the boots of those who walked
With confidence I couldn't claim,
Believing their approval was
The only path to ease my shame.

I swallowed insults like sweet wine,
Apologized for breathing air,
Made myself small enough to fit
In spaces others wouldn't dare.

The world above seemed far too bright,
Too filled with voices strong and clear,
While mine remained a trembling thing,
A sound that no one wished to hear.

But buried in that wretched form,
A secret code of change was writ,
A blueprint for a different self
That slowly, surely, came to fit.

Like caterpillars in cocoons
Who dream of flight while they dissolve,
I felt my grovelling self unmade,
My spirit finally resolve.

The transformation wasn't quick,
Nor was it painless in its course—
It required me to break apart
And reconstruct with gentle force.

I shed the skin of servitude,
Cast off the chains of others' views,
Stood upright for the first time and
Discovered skies of endless blues.

My voice emerged from silence deep,
My thoughts took shape in vibrant hues,
My heart, once muffled, now proclaimed
Its right to feel, to love, to choose.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I walk with head held high,
No longer bound to earth and dust—
I've learned, at last, to touch the sky.

From Dust to Divinity

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed against cold stone,
Fingers clawing at the earth
As if it were a throne.

I made myself so very small,
A speck upon the floor,
Believing that my lowliness
Would open mercy's door.

I wore my shame like royal robes,
My fear, a crown of thorns,
I genuflected to the world
From dusk till breaking dawn.

My words were soft apologies,
My thoughts were drenched in doubt,
My spirit—caged and cowering—
Had forgotten how to shout.

I praised the boots that stepped on me,
Thanked hands that dealt me pain,
Convinced that I deserved no more
Than bitter loss and shame.

The mirror showed a stranger's face,
Eyes downcast, shoulders bent,
A human form designed to plead,
To bow and to repent.

But deep within that broken shell,
A truth refused to die:
That I was born of stardust too,
A child of earth and sky.

This knowledge, buried, bided time
Beneath my servile skin,
Waiting for the perfect hour
To let rebirth begin.

It started as a whisper first,
A question in the night:
What if the ground I kissed was meant
To launch me into flight?

What if the hands that scraped the dirt
Were fashioned to create?
What if the heart that feared to beat
Had symphonies to make?

The revelation shook me like
An earthquake from within,
Cracking all the walls I'd built
To keep my smallness in.

I rose an inch, and then a foot,
My spine unfurled like flame,
I filled my lungs with air that felt
Like freedom without shame.

The sky, once distant, met my gaze,
The horizon stretched anew,
As I reclaimed the dignity
That had always been my due.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that self I've laid to rest.
Now I stand in radiance,
Divine like all the rest.

Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
Prostrate before false gods and kings,
My forehead pressed against the dust,
My spirit bound with iron rings.

I made my home among the low,
The broken and the cast aside,
Believing worth was something earned
Through suffering and wounded pride.

I sought approval like a drug,
Addiction to the nods of those
Whose power seemed to dwarf my own,
Whose thorns I mistook for a rose.

My voice—a trembling, timid thing—
Would crack before it formed a word,
My thoughts remained unspoken dreams,
My deepest truths remained unheard.

I wore invisibility
Like armor against judgment's eye,
Perfected the art of shrinking down
Until I barely occupied

The space allotted to my form,
The air I scarcely dared to breathe,
The moments that I passed through life
Like shadows underneath the eaves.

How strange it is to think of now,
That former self so bent and small,
Who thought the world too vast to hold
Her hopes and fears and dreams and all.

For something shifted in the dark,
A revelation soft and slow:
That grovelling served no purpose but
To keep me tethered, bound, and low.

Perhaps it was a stranger's word,
A book that fell into my hands,
A moment when the universe
Revealed its more expansive plans—

Whatever sparked the change in me,
It spread like wildfire through my veins,
Illuminating corners where
My power had remained in chains.

I felt my shoulders straighten first,
My gaze lift upward to the light,
My voice emerge with newfound strength,
My spirit ready for its flight.

The transformation wasn't kind;
It burned away what couldn't last,
The false beliefs, the toxic thoughts,
The chains that bound me to my past.

But from those ashes rose a self
I'd glimpsed in only distant dreams,
A being neither high nor low
But perfectly, completely me.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I walk in balanced grace,
No longer bowing, no longer proud—
Just present in my rightful place.

The Unfolding

I was a grovelling creature once,
Curled tight against life's bitter cold,
My eyes fixed firmly on the ground,
My story left untold.

I learned to make myself so small
That I could slip through narrow cracks,
Avoiding notice, seeking peace
In shadows at my back.

I measured worth by others' words,
By nods of their approval gained,
I drank rejection like strong wine
Until my soul was stained.

My hands were calloused from the years
Of scraping at closed doors and walls,
My knees were scarred from countless times
I'd broken into crawls.

I thought that love must be deserved,
That dignity was something earned,
That I must prove my right to breathe
Through lessons harshly learned.

I spoke in whispers, if at all,
Afraid my voice might cause offense,
I wrapped my dreams in muted cloth
And called this deference.

The world seemed built for taller souls,
For louder hearts and bolder minds,
While I remained a footnote in
The margins of mankind.

Yet somewhere in that hunched-up form,
A question slowly took its shape:
What if this grovelling posture was
A prison, not a safe escape?

What if the ground I pressed against
Was never meant to be my home?
What if the sky I feared to face
Was where I'm meant to roam?

The thought itself felt dangerous,
A spark in drought-dry woods,
A revolution brewing in
My blood and bones and goods.

I tested it with trembling first—
A straightened back, a lifted chin,
A word spoken at full volume,
A boundary drawn within.

The world did not collapse around
My sudden claim to space and sound.
Instead, it seemed to open up,
New pathways to be found.

Each day I practiced standing tall,
Unfolding what had long been bent,
Reclaiming all the parts of me
That grovelling had spent.

I learned my voice had melodies
That others longed to hear,
That vulnerability shared
Brought connection, not the fear

That kept me bound in silence deep,
That kept me kneeling, kept me low,
That told me I must earn the right
To flourish and to grow.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But that's a chapter now complete.
I walk the earth as equal now
To every soul I meet.
