I was a grovelling creature once,
All sinew, fear, and trembling bone,
My prayers mere whimpers in the dark,
My dreams as heavy as a stone.

I wore my shame like second skin,
Apologized for drawing breath,
Believed myself unworthy of
The space between my birth and death.

The world's contempt became my truth,
I swallowed it with every meal,
Digested scorn until it formed
The lens through which I'd see what's real.

I kissed the feet that kicked me down,
Thanked those who stole what little light
Had managed to illuminate
The corners of my endless night.

I scattered pieces of myself
Like breadcrumbs leading nowhere fast,
Convinced that wholeness wasn't meant
For one whose die had long been cast.

But somewhere in that hollowed shell,
A seed of something wild remained,
A spark that neither flood nor drought
Nor coldest winter had contained.

It whispered first, then spoke aloud,
Then sang until I had to hear
That I was never meant to crawl,
That I was born to persevere.

I gathered up my scattered parts,
Reclaimed the power I'd given away,
Remembered ancient wisdom that
Had waited for this very day.

Now mountains tremble when I speak,
And oceans part when I draw near.
The stars themselves rearrange their light
To spell my name in patterns clear.

I was a grovelling creature once,
But now divinity's my claim.
The universe itself expands
To make more room for who I became.

The Ascension

I was a grovelling creature once,
Prostrate beneath expectation's heel,
My spine a question mark of doubt,
My heart too numb to truly feel.

I crawled through valleys carved by shame,
Navigated canyons cut by fear,
Believed the lie that I deserved
The darkness that had brought me here.

My hands were calloused from the stones
I gathered to construct my cage,
My voice a whisper never heard
Above society's loud rage.

I bowed before false idols built
From others' definitions of success,
Contorted into shapes unnatural,
Called it growth, but it was less.

I begged for scraps of validation,
Starved myself of self-respect,
Convinced that worth was something earned
Through others' praise and their neglect.

But deep within this broken form,
A memory of flight remained,
A cellular remembering
Of heights my soul had once attained.

It started as a tingle first,
A restlessness beneath my skin,
A hunger for a different path,
A voice that would not be hemmed in.

I stretched my limbs against the dark,
Found muscles atrophied but strong,
Discovered that my grovelling stance
Had been a choice all along.

With trembling legs I stood upright,
My face turned skyward to the sun,
Each breath expanding possibilities
Of who I was and might become.

Now watch me soar beyond the clouds,
Beyond the limits I once knew.
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now I claim what's always true:

That I am vast as any sky,
As powerful as any sea,
The grovelling creature left behind,
As I embrace what's truly me.

Resurrection

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow slithering on the ground,
My voice an echo of others' thoughts,
My presence barely making sound.

I genuflected to indifference,
Prostrated to rejection's sting,
Believed myself unworthy of
The joy that self-acceptance brings.

I fed on scraps of validation,
Lapped at puddles of false praise,
Contorted into shapes unnatural
To navigate life's complex maze.

My backbone bent from carrying
The weight of others' expectations,
My spirit crushed beneath the stones
Of constant, cruel negations.

I apologized for breathing,
For taking up the smallest space,
For daring to exist at all
Within this vast, indifferent place.

The taste of dirt became familiar,
The view from below—my only sight.
I learned to love the darkness well,
Convinced I didn't deserve the light.

But somewhere in that broken vessel,
A spark refused to be extinguished,
A tiny flame of recognition
That would not let me be diminished.

It whispered truths I'd long forgotten:
That I was born to stand upright,
That grovelling was not my nature,
That I was meant to shine with light.

Each day I straightened just a little,
Reclaimed an inch of stolen height,
Remembered how to look ahead
Instead of down, to seek the light.

The metamorphosis was painful—
Rebirth demands its pound of flesh—
But rising from the dust of who I was,
I found myself created fresh.

Now mountains bow as I approach them,
Oceans part at my command.
I was a grovelling creature once,
But now transformed, I proudly stand.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'
responses:
People are happy when the sun rises high,
Casting golden beams across the morning sky.
They dance in meadows filled with blooming flowers,
Finding joy in life's most simple hours.

People are happy sharing meals with friends,
Where laughter flows and loneliness ends.
Breaking bread together, stories unfold,
Creating memories more precious than gold.

People are happy in quiet moments too,
Watching raindrops fall or skies of blue.
A book in hand, a cat upon the lap,
The gentle pleasure of an afternoon nap.

People are happy when they give, not take,
When kindness is the choice they freely make.
A helping hand, a listening ear,
Small gestures showing others they are dear.

People are happy creating something new,
Painting, writing, building dreams come true.
The satisfaction of a task complete,
Making something whole from parts discrete.

People are happy in connection deep,
Promises made and vows they keep.
In understanding glances, wordless touch,
Love expressed in actions, saying much.

People are happy embracing who they are,
Accepting flaws that make them singular.
Finding peace within their very soul,
Being broken, yet completely whole.

People are happy when the morning breaks
And dew-kissed grass beneath bare feet awakes
The child within, who once ran wild and free,
Before the world taught us anxiety.

People are happy sharing tales by fire,
Where embers glow and stories never tire.
The ancient dance of shadows on the wall
Reminds us we're connected, one and all.

People are happy tasting summer's yield,
Sweet berries plucked from nature's bounteous field.
The juice that stains our fingers deep with red
Speaks of earth's gifts, how we are all fed.

People are happy hearing music play,
The rhythm pulling troubles far away.
Bodies sway and minds release their grip
On worries that too easily make us trip.

People are happy watching children grow,
Their wonder at the world, their faces glow
With possibilities not yet constrained
By doubt or fear or dreams that have been chained.

People are happy finding their true voice,
Speaking truths that make their hearts rejoice.
Standing tall against the howling wind,
Knowing who they are, not who they've been.

People are happy in the arms of those
Who see their soul, not just the face they show.
In vulnerable moments, stripped of pride,
Finding there's no longer need to hide.

People are happy beneath starlit skies,
Where cosmic wonders greet their upturned eyes.
The universe expands within their mind,
Connecting them to all of humankind.

People are happy with soil-covered hands,
Planting seeds of hope in waiting lands.
Nurturing growth with patience, love, and care,
Creating beauty for all souls to share.

People are happy when they learn to see
The extraordinary in simplicity.
A child's laughter, leaves upon the breeze,
Life's magic found in moments such as these.

People are happy breaking from routine,
Exploring paths where they have never been.
Adventure calls to spirits brave and bold,
New chapters waiting, stories to be told.

People are happy when they find their tribe,
Those kindred souls with whom they can confide.
No judgment cast, no need for false pretense,
Just acceptance in its purest sense.

People are happy letting go of pain,
Forgiving those who caused their hearts to strain.
Release brings freedom, lightness to the soul,
Healing wounds to make the spirit whole.

People are happy living in the now,
Not dwelling on the past or wondering how
The future might unfold its mystery,
But savoring life's present tapestry.

People are happy when the ocean sings
Its ancient song of deep and timeless things.
Salt-kissed air fills lungs with wild delight,
As waves dance endlessly by day and night.

People are happy gathering to feast,
Breaking bread with strangers, friends, and priest.
Cultural barriers melt away with wine,
As stories shared make moments feel divine.

People are happy crafting with their hands,
Creating objects no one else plans.
The mind at peace when focused on the task,
In flow state where no questions need to ask.

People are happy when they help someone
Overcome a challenge, see what can be done
When kindness guides the actions that we take,
What difference one small gesture yet can make.

People are happy finding their true path,
Not following crowds or fearing others' wrath.
Authenticity brings peace profound,
When inner compass points to solid ground.

People are happy dancing in the rain,
Embracing joy and washing away pain.
Childlike wonder at the world around,
In puddle splashes, such delight is found.

People are happy in community,
Belonging, purpose, and immunity
From isolation's cold and bitter sting,
Together voices rise, together sing.

People are happy walking forest trails,
Where ancient trees tell their wordless tales.
Dappled light falls through the canopy,
Illuminating life's complexity.

People are happy sharing homemade bread,
The scent of comfort rising overhead.
Breaking crust with loved ones gathered near,
Creates connections that we hold most dear.

People are happy losing track of time,
When passion projects reach their perfect prime.
The world falls away, focus crystal clear,
Creative spirit feeling most sincere.

People are happy watching sunrise glow,
As golden light makes shadows shorter grow.
Beginning days with gratitude and peace,
Allowing anxious thoughts their sweet release.

People are happy swimming in cool lakes,
Where summer heat a gentle exit makes.
Buoyant bodies floating without care,
With water's embrace and sun-warmed air.

People are happy finding common ground,
Where differences no longer feel profound.
Humanity connects beyond all creeds,
When we acknowledge universal needs.

People are happy leaving footprints small,
Treading lightly, caring for us all.
Protecting earth for generations hence,
With actions born of love, not recompense.

Accepting flaws that make them singular.
In finding purpose, helping others grow,
Creating ripples wherever they may go.

So seek the happiness that dwells within,
Beyond material wealth or worldly din.
For joy resides in how we choose to be,
In loving fully, living truthfully.

People are happy in the strangest ways,
Not just in sunshine, but in stormy days.
They find their joy in corners unexpected,
In broken pieces somehow reconnected.

People are happy when they lose their maps,
When plans dissolve and certainty collapses.
Some find their bliss in wandering astray,
Discovering paths that weren't there yesterday.

The woman singing in an empty room,
The man who plants a garden doomed to bloom
Long after he has turned to dust and soil—
They're happy in their seemingly futile toil.

People are happy holding weathered hands,
As time erodes what youth once understands.
They're happy in the silence between words,
In messages too deep to be disturbed.

The artist staring at a blank canvas,
The writer facing pages, cavernous,
Find happiness in possibility,
In chaos waiting for identity.

People are happy when they finally see
Their reflection without scrutiny,
When they embrace the person they've become,
Not who they're told they should be by someone.

People are happy in collective grief,
Finding connection brings a strange relief.
In shared humanity when sorrows blend,
We learn that suffering need not be the end.

People are happy, yes, but also more—
Complex creatures walking toward a shore
They cannot see but somehow know exists,
Beyond the veil of life's mysterious mists.

People are happy when the morning breaks,
And consciousness from slumber slowly wakes.
They stretch their limbs beneath warm cotton sheets,
As daylight through the curtains gently seeps.

People are happy sharing coffee steam,
Discussing fragments of last night's dream.
In quiet kitchens, toast and marmalade,
Simple pleasures from which memories are made.

The office worker finds unexpected joy
In colored sticky notes she might employ
To brighten mundane tasks that fill her day,
Transforming work into a form of play.

People are happy tending garden rows,
Dirt beneath their nails, sweat on their clothes.
Connected to the earth in primal ways,
Watching life emerge through patient days.

The elderly man feeding park pigeons,
Finding purpose in these small decisions.
His laughter mingling with the cooing birds,
More eloquent than any spoken words.

People are happy in community,
Festivals where strangers come to be
United by the music and the dance,
Surrendering to rhythm and to chance.

In hospitals where newborns take first breath,
In hospices where souls prepare for death,
People find happiness in truth revealed—
That life's significance cannot be concealed.

People are happy reading dog-eared books,
Exchanging meaningful, extended looks.
In crafting something with their own two hands,
In leaving footprints on forgotten sands.

People are happy—what a strange, brief gift,
To feel the heart inexplicably lift.
To be alive and conscious of this fact,
Is miracle enough to counteract
The weight of all our human suffering,
And make our souls, despite it all, still sing.

People are happy beneath starlit skies,
Where cosmic wonders greet their upturned eyes.
They ponder vast infinities above,
Finding perspective for their human love.

People are happy in the smallest things:
A perfect peach, a dragonfly's bright wings,
The scent of rain on sun-warmed summer streets,
The rhythm of their own heart as it beats.

The fisherman who sits by tranquil lakes,
Finds joy in every ripple water makes.
Not in the catch, but in the waiting game,
Each moment never quite the same.

People are happy building homes from scratch,
Designing doorways, choosing roof to thatch.
Creating spaces where their souls can rest,
Where they can welcome life with open chest.

In classrooms where a child first understands
The power knowledge places in their hands,
The teacher and the student both alight
With happiness that comes from newfound sight.

People are happy breaking bread with friends,
Around a table where the evening spends
Itself in conversation, deep and true,
Revealing aspects previously unknown.

The couple dancing in their living room,
No music but the tune they both assume
Exists between their bodies as they sway,
No audience but memories they'll replay.

People are happy when they find their voice,
When silence breaks because they make the choice
To speak their truth, regardless of the cost,
Reclaiming parts of self they thought were lost.

In reconciliation after strife,
In second chances granted late in life,
People discover happiness anew,
In bridges built where chasms once grew.

People are happy—what a strange delight,
To be aware of darkness and of light,
And choose to turn our faces to the sun,
Embracing life until our days are done.

People are happy when they shed disguise,
And stand authentic under truthful skies.
No longer burdened by pretended selves,
But living from the core where spirit dwells.

People are happy in the act of give,
Not merely taking what they can to live.
The open palm that offers without thought
Of what return such kindness might have brought.

The mountain climber reaching summit peak,
Exhausted, breathless, muscles sore and weak,
Yet filled with joy that borders on divine—
A happiness no words can quite define.

People are happy swimming ocean deep,
Or running miles while others are asleep.
In pushing boundaries of flesh and bone,
Discovering strengths previously unknown.

The artist lost in colors, shapes, and lines,
Where time dissolves and consciousness refines
Into creative flow, a sacred space
Where happiness and purpose interlace.

People are happy gathered 'round the fire,
Telling stories that will never tire.
Ancestral echoes in each tale retold,
Connecting young to wisdom of the old.

In forest walks where sunlight filters green,
And mysteries of nature intervene
To remind us we're part of something vast,
A living present linked to ancient past.

People are happy when they feel they're heard,
When someone treasures every spoken word.
In conversations lasting until dawn,
Where masks and social barriers are gone.

The parent watching as their child discovers
A world of wonders that around them hovers.
Vicarious joy through innocent eyes,
A happiness that multiplies and flies.

People are happy in forgiveness found,
In letting go of grudges tightly bound.
The lightness that replaces heavy heart,
When healing has the chance to truly start.

People are happy—what a curious thing,
This state of being that makes spirits sing.
A choice, a gift, a practice, and a grace,
That helps us navigate this human race.

I trace the outline of what once was,

The desert creeps with patient hunger,

A turtle surfaces for breath,

# The Oasis Farewell

The date palms droop their fronds in thirst,

The moisture that brings no relief.

Around these pools, the stories tell,
Great lovers met in moonlit tryst,

In nights when stars and water kissed.

The merchants rested weary bones

While children splashed and women sang,
Their voices rising with the winds.

But now the silence weighs like stone,
The birds have sought more generous skies,
The nomads changed their ancient routes—
An era ends before my eyes.

I dip my flask into the pool,
The water cloudy, warm, and thin,
Yet still I drink with reverence
For what has been and might have been.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,

Our children grow like summer weeds,

Quiet walks as husband and wife.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
But in their depths, I've come to see
That time's true measure isn't length
But how completely we can be.

Of earth renewed by gentle rains.

Small sanctuaries that contain
The wisdom of forgotten ways.

Until the searcher is complete.

Escaping war and crushing woe,

The boat was small, the waves were high,

While parents whispered lullaby,
To drown the dangers lurking near.

The stars above, our only guide,
As compass broke and hope grew thin,
With prayers that morning's gentle tide
Would bring us to our promised kin.

Of courage shown by young and old,
Of strength that conquered desperate fear.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
We spotted land through misty veil,
Our hearts with gratitude aglow,
As wind at last filled our sail.

A new beginning waited there,
On shores unknown but full of hope,
Where we would build with tender care
A life beyond mere ways to cope.

Now decades later, I recall
That journey through the darkness deep,
And honor those who risked it all,
That promises we might all keep.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'
responses:
# Echoes from Long Ago

When whispers traveled through valleys low,
And ancient spirits served as their keeper.

I wandered paths where ancestors tread,
Their footprints faded but never gone,
Following voices of the long-dead,
Their wisdom carried from dusk till dawn.

The moon hung heavy, a silver eye,
Watching over memories lost to time,
As ghostly figures went drifting by,
Their stories woven in spectral rhyme.

The trees stood witness, their branches bare,
Reaching like fingers toward clouded skies,
While history's weight hung in the air,
And truth was hidden in centuries' lies.

I felt the presence of those before,
Their joys and sorrows, their love and pain,
As if the veil between worlds grew thin,
Allowing past and present to remain

Entwined together like lover's hands,
Inseparable despite time's flow,
Connected through invisible strands,
One dark, dark night--it was long ago.

# The Night That Changed Everything

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When innocence still cloaked my restless soul,
Before life's tempests taught me what I know,
Before my heart had paid its heavy toll.

The village slumbered under midnight's veil,
While I, a child of merely thirteen years,
Slipped from my window, followed hidden trail,
Abandoning my childhood's sheltered spheres.

The forest welcomed with its ancient song,
A symphony of creatures, wind, and leaves,
I felt at once both vulnerable and strong,
As moonlight filtered through the tangled eaves.

It was that night I witnessed something strange,
A light that danced between the elder trees,
A presence that would permanently change
The way I understood life's mysteries.

A figure formed of mist and silver glow,
With eyes that held the wisdom of the stars,
Revealed to me what few are blessed to know:
That boundaries of reality have bars

That sometimes bend for those who dare to see
Beyond the veil of ordinary sight.
The spirit world reached out and set me free,
One dark, dark night--it was long ago.

# Ancestral Memories

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When I discovered truth within the soil,
Where generations' blood and tears still flow,
Where history's hands continue still to toil.

My grandmother had spoken of this place,
This hallowed ground where ancestors still speak,
Where time itself moves at a different pace,
Where strength is found by those who dare to seek.

I knelt upon the earth and closed my eyes,
My palms pressed firmly on the dampened ground,
And suddenly, to my complete surprise,
I heard their voices—such a haunting sound.

They spoke of struggles I had never known,
Of courage in the face of brutal pain,
Of building lives from nothing but a stone,
Of finding joy despite the falling rain.

I felt their callused hands upon my face,
Their whispered wisdom flowing through my veins,
Their sacrifice providing me the grace

That penned the words my lover never wrote

The candle flickered, casting shadows tall
Against the walls of what was once our home,
While outside, rain began to softly fall,
A gentle soundtrack to my thoughts that roam.

I packed my meager treasures in a bag:
Some photographs, a book of favorite verse,
A silver locket, slightly worn and ragged,
The keys to doors I'd never more traverse.

The floorboards creaked beneath my careful steps,
As if the house itself mourned my retreat,
While memories flowed forth like bitter depths
Of waters rising round my steady feet.

I paused before the threshold, looked behind
At everything I'd built across the years,
Then stepped into the night, leaving confined
The person I had been, along with fears

That once had kept me tethered to this place.
The darkness wrapped around me like a shawl,
As freedom painted wonder on my face,
One dark, dark night--it was long ago.

When ancient barriers between worlds did flow

When suddenly the sky above my quest
Began to shift and shimmer, then unfold.

A vessel made of light and strange design
Descended slowly through the parting clouds,
Its surface etched with symbols, each a sign
Of civilizations hidden behind shrouds

Of distance so immense our minds can't grasp
The vastness of the journey they had made.
I felt my understanding start to clasp
At truths for which we humans were not made.

They spoke without a sound, mind touching mind,
Revealing cosmic secrets, ancient lore,
The interconnectedness of all mankind
With beings we had never known before.

They showed me visions of potential fates,
Of paths humanity might choose to go,
Of wisdom waiting at unopened gates,
One dark, dark night--it was long ago.

The knowledge they imparted changed my soul,
Transformed my understanding of our place
Within a universe whose greater whole
Encompasses dimensions, time, and space.

I've carried this encounter through the years,
A silent witness to a greater truth,
While watching as humanity's deep fears
Prevent the transformation of our youth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'
responses:
Fire:
A dance of crimson and gold,
Consuming all in its path with fierce hunger.
It begins as a whisper, a tiny spark
That grows with each breath of wind,
Transforming into a roaring beast.

I watch it devour the logs in the hearth,
Crackling stories of forests once standing tall,
Of sunlight filtered through leaves,
Now released in a blaze of glory.

Fire warms the coldest nights,
Bringing comfort to shivering souls,
Yet the same flame that heals can destroy,
Reducing cities to ash and memories.

In ancient times, they worshipped you,
Prometheus' gift, stolen from gods,
The beginning of civilization,
The tool that separated us from beasts.

You forge metal, cook food, light darkness,
A faithful servant when respected,
A merciless master when unleashed.
You dance in lovers' candles,
And rage in warriors' torches.

Fire, you are transformation incarnate,
Neither creating nor destroying,
But changing everything you touch
Into something new, something different,
Leaving behind only the essence of what was.

In your embers, I see the cycle of life,
The necessary destruction before rebirth,
The phoenix rising from your ashes,
Promising that even after devastation,
Life finds a way to begin again.

Fire:
It starts with a single match struck against stone,
A humble beginning for something so fierce.
The flame licks upward, hungry and alone,
Seeking more fuel as its heat begins to pierce.

I've always been drawn to its hypnotic sway,
The way it dances without choreography.
How it speaks in crackles, having much to say,
Writing stories in smoke, a burning biography.

Fire cleanses forests to make way for new growth,
A necessary destruction that brings life anew.
It cooks our meals and warms our homes, yet both
Comforts and dangers in its nature accrue.

In ancient caves, our ancestors gathered 'round
The first controlled flames, eyes wide with wonder.
This mastery of elements profoundly found
A way to push the threatening night asunder.

Fire forges metal, hardens clay to stone,
Transforms raw ingredients to culinary art.
It signals rescue when we're lost and alone,
And kindles passion within the human heart.

I've seen it rage through buildings, wild and free,
Consuming memories, treasures, and dreams.
The same element that brings such jubilee
Can devastate more quickly than it seems.

From ceremonial pyres to Olympic torch,
From birthday candles to cremation flame,
Fire marks our passages as we scorch
A path through life that's never quite the same.

In every culture, every land and age,
Fire symbolizes transformation's power.
It represents both wisdom and rage,
Both ending moments and beginning hours.

Fire:
Elemental force of transformation,
You begin as nothing but potential,
A chemical reaction waiting to happen,
Invisible until the moment of ignition.

I remember my grandfather's calloused hands
Stacking kindling in the old wood stove,
How he taught me to respect your hunger,
To feed you slowly, deliberately.

You've been humanity's companion
Since we first emerged from darkness,
Huddled in caves, afraid of shadows,
Until you showed us how to cast our own.

Fire of inspiration, burning in the mind,
Illuminating pathways previously unseen,
Consuming old ideas to make space for new ones,
Leaving behind the ash of what no longer serves.

Fire of passion, coursing through veins,
The heat of love, desire, and determination,
That warms us from within during coldest trials,
Fueling us forward when strength seems gone.

Fire of destruction, raging uncontrolled,
Forests reduced to blackened skeletons,
Homes vanishing in your insatiable appetite,
Dreams and histories ascending as smoke.

Fire of renewal, clearing what has died,
Making fertile soil from what was stagnant,
Teaching us that endings are beginnings,
That loss creates space for something new.

I've watched you in campfires under stars,
In candles on birthday cakes year after year,
In furnaces forging tools of creation,
In hearths that have warmed generations.

You are the sun that grows our food,
The electricity powering our modern lives,
The combustion driving us forward,
The metaphor for all that burns within us.

Fire:
Tongues of orange lick the midnight air,
Consuming oxygen with greedy haste.
I stand transfixed, unable to look away
From your primal beauty, your terrible grace.

You were the first technology we tamed,
Yet never fully domesticated.
Even in hearths and lanterns, contained,
Your wild nature remains unabated.

I've seen you bring life in winter's embrace,
Fingers outstretched toward your warmth.
I've watched you take life in summer's drought,
Forests crumbling beneath your touch.

Fire of the sun, distant yet essential,
Powering photosynthesis, feeding all life.
Fire of the earth, bubbling from volcanoes,
Reshaping landscapes in violent rebirth.

Fire of industry, forging steel and glass,
Building civilizations from raw elements.
Fire of war, weaponized destruction,
Leaving scars across human history.

You burn in metaphor throughout our language:
The fire in her eyes, his fiery temperament,
Fired with enthusiasm, fired from a job,
Under fire, playing with fire, fire sale.

We are drawn to you like moths,
Mesmerized by your unpredictable dance,
By the shadows you cast, stories you tell,
By your constant motion, never the same twice.

In meditation, I imagine you burning away
All that no longer serves me, all that weighs me down.
You consume my doubts, my fears, my regrets,
Transforming them to light and warmth and purpose.

Fire, you teach us impermanence,
How quickly something solid becomes ash,
How what took years to grow can vanish in moments,
How we must appreciate what exists now.

Fire:
Catalyst of change, devourer of worlds,
You begin as possibility, as potential energy
Stored in wood, in coal, in oil, in atoms,
Waiting for the right conditions to transform.

I remember my first encounter with your power:
A campfire beneath a canopy of stars,
The way you painted faces in amber light,
Made shadows dance like spirits on ancient cave walls.

Fire of creativity, burning in artists' souls,
Demanding expression, release, manifestation.
The fever that keeps poets awake at night,
Composers hearing symphonies in flames.

Fire of revolution, spreading through crowds,
Ideas igniting minds previously dormant,
The collective heat of humanity's desire
For justice, for change, for something better.

Fire of the hearth, center of home and family,
Where stories are shared and meals prepared,
Where generations gather in your glow,
Finding comfort in your consistent presence.

Fire of industry, powering furnaces and engines,
Transforming raw materials into civilization's tools,
Both savior and destroyer of environments,
Your smoke signals progress and warning.

You've been worshipped as deity, feared as demon,
Used for signals, for ceremonies, for survival.
You've cleared paths through forests and fields,
Making way for new growth, new beginnings.

I've seen your aftermath: blackened landscapes
That appear devastated, yet hold promise.
The first green shoots emerging from ash,
Life's persistence despite apparent destruction.

Fire, you remind us of our own mortality,
How quickly our constructions can fall,
Yet also how resilient we can be,
Rising from devastation with renewed purpose.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'We meet many people in life,'

Reuniting after long journeys apart.

Forcing growth through painful confrontations,
Their harshness a gift we recognize too late.

We meet many people in life,
Each one a universe unto themselves,
A constellation of experiences, dreams, and wounds,
Intersecting with our own for reasons beyond comprehension.

Others through their absence,
All of them cartographers
Mapping the territories of our becoming.

# The Human Tapestry

We meet many people in life,
Threads of various colors and strengths,
Weaving in and out of our existence,
Some barely touching the edges,
Others becoming the warp and weft
Of our very being.

And pockets full of impossible dreams,
Who taught us courage before we knew its name,
Now just a faded photograph and wondering.

The teacher whose words became lanterns,
Illuminating paths we never knew existed,
Their voice still echoing decades later
When we stand at life's crossroads.

The lover whose touch rewrote our skin,
Whose departure hollowed out spaces
We didn't know existed within us,
Leaving rooms we now fill with other loves.

The stranger on the train whose story,
Shared in the liminal space between destinations,
Shifted something fundamental in our worldview,
Though we never learned their name.

The child who made us ancestors,
Who teaches us our own reflection
And the terrifying beauty of vulnerability,
Who loves us despite knowing our flaws.

We meet many people in life,
Each encounter a brushstroke on our canvas,
Each conversation a note in our symphony,
Together creating the masterpiece
Of our shared humanity.

Like stones along a riverbed,
Some smooth from years of gentle currents,
Others jagged, newly fallen from cliffs above.

The barista with the crooked smile
Who remembers your order without asking,
A small kindness that carries you
Through gray Monday mornings.

Teaching you boundaries
You never knew you needed.

No textbook could contain.

The shell you'd built around yourself.

Restoring wonder to a world

Some lasting decades, others mere moments,
All of them necessary crossings.

Riding the carousel of existence,
Some mounting golden horses beside us,
Others merely glimpsed from across the turning wheel.

Upon which we built impossible dreams.

Revealing the beautiful complexity

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

At the Highways of Woes

I stand at the crossroads where sorrow flows,
Endless ribbons of asphalt stretching beyond sight.
At the highways of woes, where broken dreams compose
A symphony of sighs that echo through the night.

Tires screech against the weathered ground,
Leaving marks like scars upon the earth.
Headlights pierce the darkness, yet no peace is found
For travelers seeking shelter, meaning, worth.

Each mile marker counts regrets instead of distance,
Each exit promises relief but leads to more despair.
The median divides not lanes but persistence—
On one side surrender, on the other, the will to dare.

Rain falls like tears upon my windshield glass,
Distorting visions of what lies ahead.
Memories flood the rearview as landscapes pass,
Ghosts of choices made and words unsaid.

Fellow wayfarers drift by, eyes fixed forward,
Each carrying burdens invisible yet heavy as stone.
We nod in silent recognition, our journeys mirrored,
United in our separate struggles, yet profoundly alone.

At the highways of woes, toll booths collect not coins
But pieces of ourselves we cannot spare.
Yet still we drive on as dawn and dusk joins,
Hoping somewhere the road leads to repair.

CONCRETE RIVERS

At the highways of woes, I've watched shadows grow long,
Concrete rivers that carry the weight of our pain.
Streams of metal and glass where sorrows belong,
Where hope evaporates like summer rain.

These arteries of anguish pump through the land,
Feeding cities with heartache, towns with despair.
The white lines blur beneath my trembling hand,
As I navigate grief too heavy to bear.

Once I dreamed these roads led somewhere bright,
To promised lands of plenty, of peace, of rest.
Now I know they circle back into the night,
An ouroboros of suffering, humanity's test.

The homeless huddle beneath overpasses,
Seeking shelter from storms both real and within.
While above them, the fortunate masses
Race toward destinations they'll never begin.

At these crossroads of sorrow, these junctions of pain,
Where billboards sell happiness we cannot afford,
I've learned that our journeys are never in vain
If we stop to help others whose spirits are torn.

For at the highways of woes, we're all passing through,
Temporary travelers on asphalt and stone.
What matters is not where we're racing to,
But who we lift up when they can't walk alone.

THE CARTOGRAPHY OF GRIEF

At the highways of woes, I unfold my map,
Creased and worn like the lines on my face.
Each route marked with losses I cannot recap,
Each detour a memory I cannot erase.

The legend shows symbols for heartbreak and loss,
For dreams that have withered before they could bloom.
For bridges burned down that I cannot recross,
For light that was swallowed by infinite gloom.

I've traveled these byways for decades it seems,
Through landscapes of anguish and valleys of doubt.
Navigating by stars that no longer gleam,
Searching for exits I cannot make out.

The toll booths demand payment in tears and in blood,
The guardrails have failed me time after time.
I've crashed through emotions, been stuck in the mud,
And weathered storm seasons of reason and rhyme.

Fellow travelers pass with their windows rolled up,
Their eyes fixed ahead on some distant mirage.
They drink bitter coffee from a half-empty cup,
Their vehicles loaded with emotional baggage.

At the highways of woes, there are no rest stops,
No comfortable places to gather your thoughts.
The journey continues until your heart drops,
Or until you discover what can't be bought.

Yet sometimes at dusk when the light filters through,
I glimpse something sacred in this pilgrimage.
A purpose emerges from pain I've been through,
A wisdom distilled from grief's bitter edge.

RUSH HOUR LAMENTATIONS

At the highways of woes, we inch forward in line,
Bumper to bumper in our metal cocoons.
Each face illuminated by dashboard shine,
Eyes hollow as the passing of too many moons.

We clutch steering wheels like life preservers,
Knuckles white with the strain of holding on.
We are reluctant travelers, fervent observers
Of landscapes that shift from dusk until dawn.

The radio crackles with promises hollow,
Advertisements for happiness we cannot buy.
We switch stations frantically, desperate to swallow
Any distraction from the truth we deny.

At the highways of woes, exit signs taunt us—
'Relief,' they proclaim, 'Comfort,' they swear.
But each ramp leads back to the roads that haunt us,
Circular journeys that lead nowhere.

I've seen mothers weeping behind tinted windows,
Businessmen shouting at voices on phones.
Teenagers texting their digital innuendos,
Elderly drivers navigating alone.

We are pilgrims without shrines, seekers without maps,
Commuters between birth and that final rest.
Our vehicles become confessionals perhaps,
Where we whisper the truths we rarely confess.

At the highways of woes, I've learned this one thing:
We're all just trying to find our way home.
Through traffic and turmoil, through whatever life brings,
No one was meant to travel this road alone.

ASPHALT PSALMS

At the highways of woes, where tarmac meets sky,
I've witnessed the sunrise bleed into the clouds.
Heard the whispered prayers of those passing by,
Felt the weight of silence that somehow screams loud.

These roads have collected our collective grief,
Absorbed our tears like rain into thirsty ground.
Every pothole a monument to brief
Moments of impact when lives turned around.

I've counted mile markers like rosary beads,
Each number a mantra, each sign a plea.
The median strip grows wildflowers and weeds—
Beauty persistent where none ought to be.

Semitrucks thunder like gods in dispute,
Motorcycles weave through traffic like fate.
Car horns punctuate arguments mute,
As strangers exchange glances of love and hate.

At the highways of woes, I've broken down twice:
Once when my engine failed near Memphis, Tennessee,
Once when I heard she had paid the final price,
And no mechanic could fix what broke in me.

Yet still I drive onward through darkness and day,
Through blizzards of sorrow and rainstorms of doubt.
Through deserts where hope seems to wither away,
Through forests of memory I can't live without.

For at the highways of woes, I've discovered this truth:
The journey itself is the meaning we seek.
The road offers wisdom to age and to youth,
If only we listen when the asphalt speaks.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'
responses:
# The Art of Disappearing

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into the creases of shadows,
Where light cannot find her trembling form.
She becomes a ghost in her own life,
Floating through rooms without leaving footprints,
Breathing so softly the air barely moves.

The world grows too loud, too demanding,
With its constant drumbeat of expectations.
Each glance feels like judgment,
Each word a potential wound.
So she builds fortresses from blankets,
Castles from closed doors,
Kingdoms in the spaces between spoken thoughts.

But hiding has its own geography—
There are caverns in silence where echoes grow louder,
Cliffs in solitude where one might fall forever.
She learns that invisibility
Is both shelter and prison,
Both mercy and punishment.

On certain days, when the sun strikes just so,
She allows a finger, a hand, a sliver of face
To emerge from her carefully constructed darkness.
These small surrenders to being seen
Are victories hard-won against fear.

For even as she wants nothing but to hide,
Something else in her longs desperately for discovery—
To be found without having to announce herself,
To be known without having to explain,
To be loved without having to deserve it.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And sometimes, hiding is exactly what saves her,
Until she gathers strength enough
To step back into her own light.

# Vanishing Act

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To dissolve like sugar in hot tea,
To become transparent as morning air.
The weight of being visible exhausts her—
All those eyes expecting performance,
All those minds making assumptions.

She practices the art of folding inward,
Of making herself smaller than yesterday,
Of speaking in a voice that doesn't disturb dust.
She wears colors that blend with wallpaper,
Chooses seats in corners, against walls,
Perfects the smile that deflects questions.

In childhood, she played hide-and-seek
Not for the thrill of being found
But for those sacred moments of invisibility,
Curled behind curtains, beneath beds,
Holding her breath like a precious stone,
Hoping the seeker might eventually give up.

What others don't understand:
Hiding isn't always about fear.
Sometimes it's about preservation,
About keeping certain parts untouched,
About saving something sacred from becoming
Just another commodity for consumption.

In her hidden places she tends to herself
Like a secret garden—watering neglected hopes,
Pruning thoughts grown too wild,
Planting seeds that need darkness to germinate.

Yet even as she disappears,
She leaves breadcrumbs for those who truly seek her—
A poem left on a table,
A peculiar arrangement of stones on a windowsill,
Laughter that escapes before she can catch it.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that hiding, paradoxically,
She finds herself more completely
Than she ever could standing in full view.

# Refuge

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the cracks of ordinary days
Like water finding its way to deeper ground.
The constant exposure of living
Wears thin her boundaries, her patience,
Until she feels like a nerve ending
Touched too often, too carelessly.

She seeks sanctuary in small spaces—
The gap between shower curtain and tile,
The hollow beneath heavy blankets,
The cocoon of car and music and motion.
Each a temporary embassy
Where she holds diplomatic immunity
From the demands of being somebody.

Her hiding isn't cowardice but strategy,
A tactical retreat to regroup forces,
To gather scattered pieces of herself
Scattered by too many winds of obligation.
In stillness, she remembers her own contours,
In silence, she can hear her original voice
Beneath the accumulated echoes of others.

She's learned that visibility has its costs—
Each revelation invites interpretation,
Each expression risks misunderstanding.
So she guards her innermost chambers
Like a mother protecting her young,
Selective about who receives the map
To her most vulnerable territories.

And yet, in her most honest moments,
She acknowledges the paradox of her longing:
To be unseen yet deeply known,
To disappear yet matter intensely,
To hide completely yet be found precisely.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that hiding finds not emptiness
But fullness—the rich soil of self
From which new growth eventually emerges,
Stronger for having been sheltered
During its most tender becoming.

# The Invisible Woman

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To shed her skin of social expectations
Like a snake slipping free of outgrown constraints.
The performance of personhood exhausts her—
Smiling when her face wants rest,
Speaking when her thoughts need silence,
Standing straight when her spirit wants to curl inward.

She becomes a collector of hiding places:
The bathroom stall at work where she breathes deeply for five stolen minutes,
The parked car where she sits watching rain trace patterns on glass,
The empty kitchen at 3 a.m. where she eats cereal in blessed solitude.
Each space a temporary autonomous zone
Where she doesn't have to translate herself for others.

People mistake her hiding for sadness or anger,
Not understanding it's more like hunger or thirst—
A fundamental need that, left unfulfilled,
Leaves her depleted, dizzy with emptiness.
She needs absence like others need presence,
Requires disconnection as desperately as some require touch.

In her hidden moments, she practices honesty—
Lets her face arrange itself according to her actual feelings,
Allows her body to occupy space without apology,
Releases the thoughts she censors in company.
This truthfulness is a luxury she cannot afford in the open,
Where vulnerability is too often mistaken for invitation.

Yet hiding has taught her to see others more clearly—
To recognize fellow disappearers by their careful movements,
To spot the subtle signs of those who also seek refuge.
She exchanges glances of recognition with them,
A secret fellowship of those who understand
The necessity of occasional vanishing.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this desire she is both utterly alone
And part of an ancient, unspoken tradition
Of those who step aside from the clamor
To preserve what matters most—
The quiet center that makes them who they are.

# Sanctuary

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become a footnote in her own story,
A whisper instead of a declaration.
The spotlight burns her skin like midday sun,
Leaving her exposed, vulnerable, seen.

She crafts invisibility like fine art—
The careful neutrality of her clothing,
The practiced quietness of her movements,
The strategic timing of her exits and entrances.
She perfects the alchemy of becoming background,
Of occupying space without drawing attention to it.

In childhood, she built forts from furniture and sheets,
Little embassies of solitude in chaotic rooms.
Now her fortifications are more sophisticated:
Earbuds that signal unavailability,
Books that serve as portable walls,
Busyness that keeps questions at bay.

What she seeks in hiding isn't escape but essence—
The distillation of self that occurs
When the performance of personhood pauses,
When the constant translation of inner to outer ceases,
When she can exist without explanation or justification.

She's discovered a secret: hiding can be holy,
A sabbath from the labor of being witnessed.
In these sacred intervals of invisibility,
She touches something authentic and untamed,
Something that withers under observation
Like certain plants that close at human touch.

Those who love her learn to respect these disappearances,
To recognize them not as rejection but as restoration.
They understand that her return is made possible
By the freedom to temporarily vanish,
That her presence is sweeter for her absences.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this wanting lives a profound wisdom—
That some treasures must be sheltered to survive,
That some strengths are cultivated in darkness,
That the most enduring parts of us
Are often those we guard most carefully.

The cocoon-time before emerging anew.

The natural end to what once began.

Setting out empty buckets to catch any rain.

Their light still traveling through space

Hoping they might somehow form a picture.

Is just another form of expression—
If the spaces between words hold as much meaning
As the carefully chosen syllables ever did.

Perhaps this emptiness is not an ending

Resting before the next season of growth.
Perhaps the poet remains, even when poetry fails.

Lingering into the velvet hours of night,
Always ready to dance when I called.

It made sense of chaos, found beauty in pain,
Transformed the ordinary into the sacred.

The well that seemed bottomless has run dry;
The faithful messenger returns with no news.

I read the masters hoping to catch their fever,
But their brilliance only illuminates my lack.

Slips away like water through cupped hands?

Stories told through the simple act of living.

I feel the sun warm my aging face
And know some truths need no expression.

Maybe the poetry hasn't left me at all,
But waits in a different form to be recognized.
Or maybe this ending is itself a poem—
The final stanza of a lifelong work.

Either way, I'll keep this pen nearby,
Ready should the words decide to return.

While discovering what remains when the verses end.

and the world continues spinning,
indifferent to this small tragedy
that feels like galaxies collapsing.

I remember the first time words found me—
I was young, heart raw with adolescent pain,
and suddenly there was this language
that could hold what seemed unholdable.

For years, I carried this gift like a torch,
illuminating dark corners of existence,
transforming ordinary moments
into something sacred, something lasting.

Now I sit with coffee gone cold,
watching the cursor blink accusingly
on an empty document, each pulse
a reminder of what has abandoned me.

I've tried all the old rituals—
walking in forests at dawn,
listening to the music that once inspired,
reading the masters until my eyes blur.

But the well has run dry,
and no amount of digging
seems to reach the underground river
that once flowed so generously.

Friends tell me it will return,
this elusive power, this magic.
They speak of cycles and seasons,
of fallow periods necessary for growth.

But what if this is permanent?
What if the muse has found
a more worthy vessel,
leaving me hollow and ordinary?

I catch myself studying strangers on trains,
wondering if they can see the difference—
can they tell I am no longer a maker of worlds
but merely a man with memories of creation?

Perhaps there is grace in this unbecoming,
in learning to be human without the armor of art.
Perhaps there is something to discover
in the silence that follows the final verse.

# Voiceless

A poet loses his power for poetry
and wonders if he was ever a poet at all.
The words that once arrived unbidden,
a blessing or a haunting,
now stay distant as stars.

I've become a tourist in my own craft,
admiring others' verses with the bitter sweetness
of watching lovers embrace
after your own heart has been broken.

Each morning, I still reach for my notebook,
a ritual as ingrained as breathing,
only to find my mind empty as winter fields,
no seeds of thought taking root,
no harvest of images to gather.

I remember how it felt—
the electric current running from brain to hand,
the way time would dissolve around me,
the strange alchemy of turning blood and memory
into stanzas that could outlive me.

Now I collect rejection letters
for poems written in better days,
each one confirming what I already know:
that whatever spark once lived in me
has found a new home elsewhere.

At parties, I still introduce myself as a writer,
the word feeling increasingly fraudulent
on my tongue. Friends ask to read new work,
and I redirect, speaking of revisions,
of projects too fragile to share.

I've tried to force it—
sitting for hours at my desk,
chasing metaphors like butterflies,
only to capture pale imitations,
lifeless things pinned to the page.

Perhaps this silence is a gift.
Perhaps the world doesn't need
another mediocre poem
about moonlight or lost love
or the passage of time.

Or perhaps this too is temporary,
a necessary emptying
before the filling begins again.
A poet without poetry is still a witness,
still a keeper of observations
that may someday find their voice.

# The Unwritten

A poet loses his power for poetry
like a tide retreating from familiar shores,
leaving behind strange artifacts
and questions without answers.

Once, I could spin gold from straw,
transform ordinary moments into eternity,
capture the flutter of a sparrow's wing
in the perfect arrangement of syllables.

The words would wake me at odd hours,
demanding to be written,
urgent as lovers' whispers,
insistent as children tugging at sleeves.

I filled notebooks with these visitations,
never questioning their source,
never imagining the well could run dry,
the visitors could cease their calling.

Now I walk through days unaccompanied
by that second sight that turned
sunsets into metaphors,
arguments into sonnets,
grief into elegies.

I read my old work with detachment,
as if it were written by a stranger,
a more gifted twin who disappeared
leaving me to explain his absence.

Colleagues speak of writer's block
as if it were a temporary illness,
a common cold of creativity
that will pass with the right remedy.

But what if it's more permanent?
What if it's the body rejecting
an organ it once needed?
What if it's evolution, not affliction?

I still notice beauty—
the perfect spiral of a shell,
the way light fractures through leaves,
the rhythm of rain against windows.

But these observations remain just that—
unalchemized, untransformed,
raw materials without a craftsman,
stories without a voice.

Perhaps there is wisdom in this silence,
in learning to be present without capturing,
in allowing moments to pass through
without trying to preserve them in amber words.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'
responses:
# The Silent Quill

A poet loses his power for poetry,
Like a bird whose wings have forgotten flight,
The words that once flowed with such clarity
Now hide in shadows, beyond his sight.

His pen hovers above the empty page,
A conductor without an orchestra,
The silence grows louder with each passing age,
As inspiration becomes a distant star.

He wanders through memories of verses past,
When metaphors bloomed like spring's first flowers,
When similes sang and rhythms held fast,
And language bent willingly to his powers.

The muse that whispered sweetly in his ear
Has vanished like morning mist in the sun,
Leaving behind a landscape stark and clear,
Where once fantastical worlds had begun.

He searches for sparks in mundane moments,
In coffee shops, subway cars, rainy streets,
But finds only hollow disappointments,
And echoes of his former lyric feats.

His bookshelves groan with the weight of masters,
Whose brilliance now seems to mock his decline,
Each volume a reminder of disasters
That stripped his soul of its creative shine.

Yet in this drought of imagination,
Perhaps there lies a different kind of verse,
A poem about the very stagnation
That feels like both a blessing and a curse.

For what is a poet without his struggle?
What meaning in art that comes without pain?
Perhaps in silence, truth begins to juggle
New patterns that will bring him home again.

# The Fading Muse

A poet loses his power for poetry
As autumn strips the trees of golden leaves,
The language that once flowed so naturally
Now stutters, falters, hesitates, and grieves.

Where once stood mountains of magnificent verse,
Now only pebbles of pedestrian thought,
Each stanza feels increasingly worse,
Each metaphor more desperately sought.

He stares at blank pages, pristine and white,
Like snowfields stretching endlessly ahead,
No footprints mark the way through darkest night,
No compass guides the path his mind once led.

Remember when the words would dance and leap,
Performing acrobatics on his tongue?
When images would surface from the deep,
And every line felt brilliantly young?

The critics praised his 'voice of generation,'
His volumes flew from overcrowded shelves,
His readings caused immense anticipation,
As listeners found reflections of themselves.

But something shifted in the universe,
Some cosmic gear has slipped its golden cog,
The blessing of his gift became a curse,
His crystal clarity transformed to fog.

He tries techniques to spark the dying flame:
Long walks at dawn, meditation, solitude,
New notebooks, fountain pens of great acclaim,
Yet nothing breaks this barren interlude.

Perhaps the silence holds its own strange gift,
A chance to listen rather than to speak,
To let the soul and spirit slowly drift,
To find new strength in places deemed too weak.

For poetry isn't merely stringing words,
But living fully in this complex world,
Observing life like flight of hummingbirds,
Experiencing joy and pain unfurled.

# Wordless

A poet loses his power for poetry
Like a sailor suddenly fearing the sea,
The instrument that once played symphonies
Now silent as stone, locked in mysteries.

I used to conjure worlds with simple phrases,
Build castles in the air with metered lines,
My words once bloomed like wildflowers in spring phases,
Now wither before reaching full designs.

The dictionary sits heavy on my desk,
A thousand doors to rooms I cannot find,
My journey now increasingly grotesque,
As language slips away from grasp of mind.

What cosmic joke is this, what cruel fate?
To take the one thing I held most divine,
To leave me here to helplessly create
Pale imitations of what once was mine.

I dream of verses flowing like clear streams,
Of metaphors that strike like lightning bolts,
Of similes that bridge reality and dreams,
Of rhythm steady as a horse that trots.

My friends still introduce me as 'the poet,'
A title that now stings with irony,
A hollow label I cannot outgrow it,
A ghost that haunts my lost identity.

I wander through the works of greater minds,
Shakespeare and Dickinson, Angelou and Yeats,
Searching for clues, for sparks, for any kinds
Of signs to guide me through these barren states.

Some days I catch a glimpse, a fleeting shadow,
Of what once came as natural as breath,
A line appears like flower in a meadow,
Then disappears, a momentary death.

Perhaps true poetry lies in the struggle,
The reaching for what seems beyond our grasp,
The beauty found when words and meaning juggle,
The human spirit's everlasting clasp.

# The Empty Inkwell

A poet loses his power for poetry
As winter claims the final autumn leaf,
The well of words, once flowing endlessly,
Now dry as desert sand, beyond belief.

I stand before the mirror, questioning
The face that stares with hollow, haunted eyes,
Is this the bard whose verses took to wing?
Whose metaphors reached far across the skies?

My notebooks gather dust on weathered shelves,
Their pages filled with ghosts of former thought,
When words aligned themselves like magic elves,
And meaning into beauty deftly wrought.

I visit cafés where I once composed
My finest works amid the bustling crowd,
But inspiration keeps its doors firmly closed,
My muse, once vocal, now will not speak aloud.

The critics wonder where my voice has gone,
My publisher sends emails filled with dread,
My readers wait for work to carry on,
While doubt and fear fill up my heart instead.

I try to force the process, stay up late,
Consuming coffee, wine, and ancient texts,
But artificial means cannot create
What once flowed freely, leaving me perplexed.

Perhaps this silence is a different verse,
A poem written in the negative space,
A chance to listen to the universe,
To find new rhythms at a slower pace.

For what is poetry but truth distilled?
And truth sometimes requires silent thought,
Perhaps my cup is simply being filled
With experiences that can't be bought.

The greatest poems often come from pain,
From struggle, loss, confusion, and despair,
Perhaps my power isn't lost in vain,
But transforming to something new and rare.

# Aphasia

A poet loses his power for poetry
Like earth might lose its gravity one day,
The words that once assembled perfectly
Now scatter, fragmenting, floating away.

I reach for language like a drowning man
Grasps desperately at passing driftwood pieces,
But sentences collapse before they can
Take form, my eloquence rapidly decreases.

The library inside my mind, once vast,
With volumes categorized and bound in gold,
Now stands with empty shelves, its glory past,
Its stories either vanished or untold.

My colleagues still invite me to their readings,
I sit in back rows, clapping politely,
While envy and regret continue breeding
A bitterness I fight against nightly.

I've tried all remedies the world suggests:
Meditation, medication, therapy,
Retreats to mountains, spiritual quests,
Each ending in the same futility.

The doctors say there's nothing wrong, physically,
No tumor pressing on my frontal lobe,
No stroke or trauma acting mischievously,
No explanation modern science can probe.

I wonder if the universe has quotas,
A certain number of poems each soul may write,
Perhaps I've simply filled my designated quota,
And now must learn to live without this light.

Or maybe words, like any natural resource,
Can be depleted through excessive use,
My decades of expression run their course,
The well gone dry from constant, heavy abuse.

Yet in this wordless void, I'm slowly learning
That poetry transcends the written line,
It lives in sunset skies and candles burning,
In children's laughter, taste of aged wine.

Perhaps true poets never lose their sight,
Just change the instruments through which they see,
Finding in silence depths of new delight,
A different kind of creativity.

responses:

Through concrete cracks and urban sprawl,

In sunshine, wind, and rain.

To wisdom's sweet release.

The sunrise every day,

There is a law which guarantees
That seeds, when planted deep,
Will stretch toward distant sunlight's call,

There is a law which guarantees

Still moments can be found.

There is a law which guarantees

There is a law which guarantees

Find paths to constitute.

The entropy of things,
A slow unraveling of order
Time inevitably brings.

The empires fade to dust,
The shining sword will dull and break,

There is a law which guarantees
That power cannot last,
That tyrants fall and kingdoms end,
Like shadows in the past.

Will someday cease to be,
As history's relentless tide
Sweeps all into its sea.

There is a law which guarantees
That knowledge seeks the light,
That truth, though buried for an age,
Will someday claim its right.

No censorship can long contain
Ideas meant to spread,
No darkness can extinguish thoughts
Once they have been said.

There is a law which guarantees
That hope endures through all,
A stubborn flame that flickers on
Refusing to fall.

There is a law which guarantees
No promise comes for free,
Each oath we make, each vow we take
Demands integrity.

The universe keeps ledgers strict,
Accounting every deed,
The balance of our actions grows
From intention to seed.

There is a law which guarantees
Connection through our pain,
The wounds we bear, when shared with care,
Become our common gain.

In vulnerability's embrace,
True strength is often found,
As rivers carve through hardest stone
To make the fertile ground.

There is a law which guarantees
That beauty finds a way,
Through cracks in our defenses built,
Light enters day by day.

The broken places in our lives
Let golden healing through,
Revealing patterns intricate
Where wholeness once we knew.

There is a law which guarantees
That nothing stays complete,
Perfection is the enemy
Of what makes life so sweet.

For in the messy in-between,
Where certainty dissolves,
The mystery of being here
Eternally evolves.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'
responses:

That every action finds its equal force,
That every kindness planted deep
Will someday find its rightful course.

Newton knew it in the physical realm,
How objects push against each other's weight,
But in the human heart and mind
The principle holds just as great.

There is a law which guarantees
That hatred sown returns as pain,
That bridges burned to ashen dust
Leave us stranded in the rain.

Yet by this same immutable truth,
Compassion offered without thought of gain
Returns to us in multitudes,
Like sunlight after days of rain.

There is a law which guarantees
That time moves forward, never back,
That moments lost to carelessness
Are gone forever, fade to black.

So in this knowledge we must live,
With purpose guiding every deed,
For what we send into this world
Comes back to us with equal speed.

There is a law which guarantees
The turning of the cosmic wheel,
The rising sun, the ocean's tide,
The way our hearts are made to feel.

It binds the stars in distant space
And holds the planets in their dance,
It whispers through the ancient trees
And guides the monarch's migratory trance.

There is a law which guarantees
That nothing truly disappears—
Energy transforms and shifts
Across the span of countless years.

The child's laugh becomes the wind,
The fallen leaf feeds new spring bloom,
The tears we shed return as rain,
All life emerges from the tomb.

There is a law which guarantees
That we are never truly free
From consequences of our choice,
From what we've done and failed to see.

Yet in this binding there is grace,
A certainty in shifting sand,
A promise that the universe
Unfolds according to some plan.

There is a law which guarantees
No certainty except for change,
A paradox that binds us all
Across life's wild and shifting range.

The mountains crumble grain by grain,
Proud empires fall to history's dust,
The mightiest oak must someday yield
To time's relentless, patient thrust.

There is a law which guarantees
That every joy must have its cost,
That sweetness tastes most poignant when
We've known what it means to be lost.

The brightest stars burn fastest, yes,
The deepest love risks deepest pain,
The fullest life embraces both
The brilliant sun and pouring rain.

There is a law which guarantees
No soul walks this earth alone,
Though paths diverge and reconnect,
We're bound by more than flesh and bone.

So in this web of cause and fate,
Of choice and chance and mystery,
We find our freedom not in flight
But in accepting what must be.

There is a law which guarantees
The equal measure of our days,
Twenty-four hours, no more, no less,
To spend in countless different ways.

The beggar and the billionaire,
The prisoner and the reigning queen,
Each granted this democracy of time,
This common wealth, this in-between.

There is a law which guarantees
That voices silenced will be heard,
That truth compressed beneath the weight
Of lies will rise, just like a bird.

The arc of justice may bend slow,
Its progress halting, often frail,
But tyranny contains the seeds
Of its inevitable fail.

There is a law which guarantees
That beauty finds a way to bloom,
In concrete cracks, in prison cells,
In hearts consumed by grief and gloom.

So hold this knowledge like a flame
When darkness seems to claim the light,
The universe has pledged itself
To balance wrong with what is right.

There is a law which guarantees
The mystery of our existence here,
A riddle wrapped in paradox,
A truth both distant and quite near.

We seek to name it, pin it down,
With science, faith, philosophy,
Yet still it slips between our words
Like water through cupped hands, you see.

There is a law which guarantees
That questions multiply with age,
That wisdom lies in knowing less
With certainty on life's strange stage.

The child asks 'why' and adults smile,
As if the answer's plainly known,
Yet in our quiet moments we
Face mysteries entirely our own.

There is a law which guarantees
Connection in our solitude,
That atoms once joined at the dawn
Remain entangled, ever fused.

So when you feel most separate,
Most isolated in your pain,
Remember: nothing stands apart
In this vast cosmic, grand refrain.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'
responses:

That every action has its price,
A cosmic balance, if you please,
That weighs our virtue and our vice.

The universe, with patient hand,
Records each deed, both foul and fair,
The kindnesses we understand,
The cruelties we barely dare.

This law transcends our human courts,
Our fleeting rules and fragile codes;
It measures thoughts of all sorts
And follows where compassion goads.

No soul escapes accountability,
Though justice moves by slow degrees,
It finds us with finality.

There is a law which guarantees
That nothing worthy disappears—
The love we give with genuine ease
Echoes throughout the coming years.

There is a law which guarantees
The turning of the silent stars,
The rhythm of the restless seas,
The healing of our deepest scars.

This ancient code, unwritten yet
Engraved in every living thing,
A promise nature won't forget
From winter's chill to blossoms' spring.

I've seen it in the patient trees
That shed their leaves but never die,
In birds that ride the autumn breeze
Then journey home across the sky.

There is a law which guarantees
That darkness cannot last for long,
That morning light will bring release
And silence yields to hopeful song.

When grief seemed endless as the night,
How slowly, like the opening flowers,
My spirit turned again toward light.

This law speaks not in human tongue
But whispers through the DNA,
In cells where life itself is strung
Along the double helix way.

There is a law which guarantees
That nothing stays exactly same,
That change, though frightening, still frees
And transformation is our aim.

So trust this law when all seems lost,
When chaos seems to rule your days,
For every river, though storm-tossed,
Will find the sea in its own ways.

There is a law which guarantees
The permanence of impermanence,

While binding us to consequence.

Through decades of uncertainty,
Observed how quickly time moves on
With ruthless regularity.

Its sand falls with precision's grace.

We cannot stop time's steady pace.

In patterns that will not betray

In blindness to reality.

The stranger and the enemy,
And see reflected in that glass

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five steps that mark our days,
A metronome of modern life
That guides our weary ways.

Awakening to darkness still,
The alarm's persistent cry,
I rise from dreams half-remembered,
As night bids its goodbye.

A desk piled high with tasks,
Meetings, deadlines, endless emails,
Behind professional masks.

Then homeward bound through crowded streets,
Where strangers pass like ghosts,
Each locked within their private worlds,
Returning to their posts.

The evening meal, a brief respite,
Perhaps some words exchanged,
Or silence filled with glowing screens,
Connections rearranged.

At last, sleep claims its rightful due,
Exhaustion takes its toll,
As consciousness surrenders
And darkness soothes the soul.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A cycle never-ending,
Yet hidden in this simple verse
Are moments worth defending.

For in the spaces in between,
The cracks of routine's wall,
Lies life in all its mystery,
The greatest gift of all.

Clockwork Lives

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep,
A mantra of the modern age,
Five stations of existence
On life's predetermined stage.

Wake to artificial light,
Dreams dissolving into air,
Consciousness returning slowly,
Reality's unspoken dare.

Work beneath fluorescent heavens,
Hours measured, bought and sold,
Trading time for compensation,
As youth surrenders unto old.

Home, that sanctuary sought,
A refuge from the world outside,
Where walls contain our treasures,
And truest feelings often hide.

Eat what time and budget allow,
Sustenance for body, sometimes soul,
Breaking bread in isolation,
Or sharing life around a bowl.

Sleep, that small rehearsal death,
Where consciousness releases hold,
Restoring what the day has taken,
As tomorrow's script unfolds.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep,
Five words that chart our course,
But what of love and wonder?
What of nature's gentle force?

Between these rigid markers,
In moments seemingly routine,
Lies the poetry of living,
The extraordinary unseen.

The Carousel of Days

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A carousel that never stops,
Spinning through the seasons,
Through summer heat and winter frosts.

I wake to darkness in December,
To birdsong in the spring,
The same eyes open to the world,
Unsure what days might bring.

I work with hands or mind or both,
Producing, serving, making,
A cog within the greater wheel,
Creating or just taking.

I journey home when day is done,
Through weather fair or foul,
To walls that know my secrets,
Where I can drop my social cowl.

I eat what comfort or health demands,
Sometimes in celebration,
Sometimes in mere necessity,
A brief, required libation.

I sleep beneath the watching stars,
Though rarely do I see them,
Dreaming dreams of different lives,
Of all I could yet be then.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Five points upon life's star,
A pattern seemingly mundane,
Yet telling who we are.

Repeated day by endless day,
We craft our brief existence,
As time continues on its way.

Five words to sum a life,
A haiku of existence,
Distilled from joy and strife.

Awakens sluggish minds?

That brightens dreary tasks?

In satisfaction basks?

Or how the dog's excited dance
Makes weariness no more?

What of the meal shared lovingly,
Prepared with thoughtful care?
Or conversations over wine
That partners gladly share?

What of the book that takes you far
Before your eyelids fall?
Or how dreams weave their magic spells
When sleep comes to call?

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
A skeleton of days,
But flesh and blood and beating heart

Between these stark necessities,
Amid life's steady beat,
Lie verses yet unwritten,

Silent guardians of the sleeping earth.
While constellations paint the skies,
Preparing for tomorrow's birth.

Undoing damage that the day has done.
